Name: Batu Ferringhi Hidden Gems
Comment: Very Relax environment, nice view and can enjoy very much. Relaxing walk is the most fun of the trip. Cold Weather too

Name: Batu Ferringhi Hidden Gems
Comment: I am local but never knew about the beautiful waterfalls hidden in our own hills. Peter is a friendly and wonderful guide and knows a lot about the hiking trails in Penang. The aqueduct is really an engineering marvel. I loved the hike through the forest  and the perfect finish was a dip into the cold and refreshing river at the end. It was a piece of paradise, with butterflies flying everywhere, the sound of the rushing stream and cicadas in the background.  It is the kind of trip you would want to do over and over again.

Name: Batu Ferringhi Hidden Gems
Comment: This is a relaxing ‚Äòmorning walk/jog‚Äô or light hike type activity, where the loop trail is about 6-7km. Fitness level required: Low, flat terrain. Attractive features: Serenity, peace, calm, pre-war rustic colonial heritage building structures within the catchment area, bathe under dam waterfall, bathe under various waterfalls and stream rock pools, mix of secluded tarred road, light forest ferny trail, and main road.The trail is through the Penang Water Authority (Malay: Perbadanan Bekalan Air (PBA)): Penang water supply agency) water catchment and processing area. The catchment area is called ‚ÄúBatu Ferringhi Aqueduct‚Äù, and associated with it, ‚ÄúBatu Ferringhi Dam‚Äù (also known as ‚ÄúBatu Ferringhi Waterfall‚Äù). The dam is a small one, more of a weir. The dam/waterfall is in an area in Batu Ferringhi unofficially called ‚ÄúChin Farm‚Äù because of a small freshwater fish farm there that draws on the stream water in that area of streams, waterfalls and stream rock pools.This trail is through secluded, quiet tarred road within the restricted access catchment area, light wild forest trail, then normal coastal main road looping back to the starting point (assuming you parked your car at the starting point).The PBA aqueduct, catchment and dam area is a restricted controlled access area. But, if you are a casual stroller or jogger, the PBA is quite flexible to let you access, traverse through, on the basis that they trust you to behave yourself.On getting to starting point. If by bus, assuming you start from Georgetown, take the government ‚ÄúRapid Transit‚Äù public bus from the town bus terminus (‚ÄúKomtar‚Äù or ‚ÄúPengkalan Weld‚Äù (Weld Quay) to Batu Ferringhi. Buses to ‚ÄúBatu Ferringhi‚Äù or ‚ÄúTelok Bahang‚Äù (one village westwards beyond ‚ÄúBatu Ferringhi‚Äù) will get you there. Alight at the ‚ÄúHoliday Inn Resort‚Äù hotel at Batu Ferringhi, along the main coastal road. (This is the area of the Batu Ferringhi night market.) The hotel is on the sea-side. Cross the main road to the land-side directly opposite. Walk upslope on ‚ÄúJalan Sungai 1‚Äù. Further upslope, you will see Uplands International School on right, at junction. Turn right at this junction. Go past this school. Further uproad/slope, you see a fenced-up ‚ÄúPasar Batu Ferringhi‚Äù (Batu Ferringhi Market), a building complex with carpark. I think this is an unused market building complex, looks abandoned and empty. Near this building complex, you see a cul-de-sac, and a blue-colored guardhouse, and a gate. This is the PBA guardhouse into the catchment area. There may or may not be a guard there. If no guard, you will see a sign-in register book, sign-in here.If you drove, park your car at this cul-de-sac. Morning walkers park their cars in this unofficial carpark.You are on a tarred road. The high ground water catchment area transports you to a serene calm world of its own. Observe the raw unprocessed water flowing in the white aqueduct. Observe the rustic classic white water-control building structures. Enjoy the serenity. You may meet some bullying, aggressive monkeys along the tarred road. Do not show that you are intimidated by them, or they will bully and harass you. Meet aggression with aggressive. Fight fire with fire. Growl at them. Stomp your feet. A hiking pole will be useful, not to hurt them, but to ward them off. Do not cower.You come to a fork, as marked by a classic cannon on elevated ground. Detour upslope to take the cannon direction, follow the road. When done, return to this cannon junction, to continue.When back to the cannon landmark, continue on the main tarred road. You will come to a tranquil dammed stream. This is ‚ÄúBatu Ferringhi Dam/Waterfall‚Äù. A mini-dam, a weir. There may or may not be waterfall water flow depending on whether it is dry or wet season. This is, sort of, the start of the so-called ‚ÄúChin Farm‚Äù area of mini-waterfall cascades, stream pools. Descend from the dam top, to the rocky stream bed bottom (parts of it above water, but slippery, be careful), via a steep path. If the waterfall and stream water are in full flourish typically in the wet/rainy season, picnic, bathe, relax here. Enjoy the natural serenity.To carry on beyond the dam, stand on the rocky stream bed, your back to the dam, facing downstream. Turn right, follow the trail. You will see an overhead huge fat water pipe, over a pretty stream rock pool.  You will pass a luxuriant area of ferns. Under bright sunlight, this green sea of ferns shimmers brilliantly, a beautiful sight.Further, you see a dull water tower structure, and a broken fence perimeter. Beyond this fence, you exit the PBA water catchment area. As you hike along the trail, you hear the sound of the stream on your right. Watch out for a rough access forest path that gets you to the rocky area of stream, mini-waterfalls and stream rockpools. This is the so-called ‚ÄúChin Farm Waterfalls‚Äù (more cascades than waterfalls) area. This is a pretty, serene area ideal for bathing, picnic, photography and chilling. It may not be much in the dry season, but is quite wonderful in the wetter months when the water is in full flow. There is a part of the stream where there is a rock depression. You can tuck yourself into this cocoon of a depression, chill, and have the stream water gush past, caressing and massaging your body. For your information, the ‚ÄúChin Farm‚Äù fish farmer‚Äôs house is downstream. You may hear his guard dogs bark.Once you are done bathing and chilling, rejoin the trail. Continue in seaward direction towards the main ‚ÄúJalan Batu Ferringhi‚Äù coastal road. On joining the main road, turn right in Georgetown-direction to get back to the PBA guardhouse starting point, if you had parked your car there. If you do this, you would have covered 6-7km in a loop.For your information, separate from the above hike, the ‚ÄúBatu Ferringhi Dam/Waterfall‚Äù is also the start-point for the ‚ÄúBatu Ferringhi - Bukit Laksamana - Penang Hill‚Äù hike, the longest, most arduous hike on the island, fitness level Medium-High, see my other Tripadvisor post on this hike.

Name: Chin Farm Waterfall
Comment: The weather is great when I went with the guide whom l hired through Trip Advisor, Mr Peter.  The farm has got excellent view of Penang. The fruits, plants are refreshing to see. The little waterfall pool is cool to soak my feet, seeing fishes swimming underneath. Definitely has to bring mosquitoes repellent, sun cap and poncho. Water bottle to drink. Do your toileting before climbing up. I enjoy the trip

Name: Chin Farm Waterfall
Comment: After posting another review on Tripadvisor, I happened on the previous reviews of this waterfall from another reviewer.  Well, I googlemapped it and it turn out to be about 1.6 kilometers from the hotel we were staying.  I figured out a route along the beach, turned into the main road and crossed it, turned left at an Indian restaurant and found the unmarked road that led into the jungle.  We hiked a few hundred meters up a gravel road.  Yes,  there were several unfinished construction sites along the gravel road and some trash but the walk was pleasant enough.After about 400 meters from the road, there was a house with some barking dogs, a small old rusting bridge, the road turned into a swampy trail.  My girlfriend and I managed to avoid the boggy parts and advanced up the rocks, following the stream to the waterfalls and there was no one there.  It was pretty.  There were some macaque monkeys chattering in the distance but they left us alone.We didn't take a dip but we just lounged around and enjoyed the butterflies and dragonflies as the dipped around the waters around our feet.   Really nice secluded spot.  Highly recommended if you are staying around this area.

Name: Chin Farm Waterfall
Comment: The location on trip advisor is misplaced. I have posted an update. Not sure it will be accepted. The road to waterfall is accompanied by tons of structural waste and is a bit stinking. The place itself is not bad but I am bot sure it worth the visit.

Name: Chin Farm Waterfall
Comment: This was worth the short walk but directions were confusing as one site said 1.7 kms and another said 5.6kms. We walked the first part and followed the helpful directions from other reviews re turning at cafe. However we then tried walking to the 2nd site shown but never made it as it was confusing where ithe falls were and after 60mins walking in the hot sun we went to Monkey Beach and hired a boat back to the Park Royal and it was really cheap! Great adventure though!

Name: Chin Farm Waterfall
Comment: This was a great find!!!The locations is correct on Googlemaps, so is easy to find and it is about a 10 min walk up from the main road. Its a dirt/road and there were numerous trucks and heavy machinery digging along the sides, so it was pretty muddy.In early-December 2018 there was a raging waterfall because of all of the recent rain. And it was spectacular.There is an area which could be used as a car park & it is an easy few min up some steps to get to the top of the rocks.Well worth getting off the main road and exploring this waterfall

Name: Chin Farm Waterfall
Comment: A short 12 minute walk along a flat track (located opposite Bayview, track begins next to VSassy Cafe).  Walk straight until you see Chin Farm Carpark sign, then veer left over small bridge.  The waterfall itself was clean and pleasant enough, but all around people had left rubbish behind them, such a shame.  Still nice for a small 'jungle' walk with young kids and a quick wade.

Name: Chin Farm Waterfall
Comment: Underrated place. Best adventure at penang Island. No room for changing so just remember to be in ur swim suit clothes when u go there..

Name: Chin Farm Waterfall
Comment: I visited the waterfall back in 1987 when the path leading to the place was fringed with trees and vegetation. In a visit in April 2018 with my wife, we learned that the path is now essentially an eyesore with rubbish strewn willy-nilly and the landscape appears to be used as a landfill site. It was painful to see nature being treated in such a manner. The environmental protection authorities (if they ever decide to undertake any proper investigation/enforcement work) should conduct a visit to the place without delay!However the waterfall itself is a great place. We got there early around 8.30 am and had the whole place to ourselves except for a troop of macaque monkeys basking in the sun on boulders. Be careful when climbing up the waterfall as it can be very slippery due to moss growing on parts where the flow of the water isn't strong. It was fantastic to immerse ourselves in breathtaking series of cascades fringed by forest foliage then plunge right into refreshing pools.The volume of the cascade would depend on the extent of recent rain, which would increase or decrease the flow. In the dry season you may find only trickles of water. Children (well supervised) would love the experience!

Name: Chin Farm Waterfall
Comment: nice small hike with 1y and 3y children.Very easy to find and absolutly not crowd.Perfect to start a day for tourism

Name: Chin Farm Waterfall
Comment: This Batu Ferringhi River with its many waterfalls is located in Batu Ferringhi and the entrance is across the road from Bayview beach Hotel. We had been coming here since our young days and that was our favourite getaway. The water flowing down here is the runoff from the Batu Ferringhi Dam. Hiking trails here lead to Teluk Bahang, Balik Pulau, Western Hill - Botanical Gardens and Penang Hill. During our Girl Guides and Ranger days, we had ventured and explored all the trails together with the Boy Scouts and Rovers. The waterfalls were bigger then as water was more abundant. Now runoff has been tapped and redirected to the many farms along its banks. Still it is a nice getaway to spend a couple of hours with Mother nature.

Name: Chin Farm Waterfall
Comment: Bring your togs sunscreen smiles sun-hats cameras and friends best after some rain which can be regular and just have a fun time- we did and enjoy ...

Name: Chin Farm Waterfall
Comment: it was a bit of a hike but worth it the water was cold and refreshing there was no parking but we went with a driver who stayed with us for the day and it was worth adding to our trip.

Name: Chin Farm Waterfall
Comment: Although not easy to find [hint:  go to the shops opposite the Bayview hotel in  Batu Ferringhi and ask the people working there] it is worth the effort.  The trails take one through "light jungle", gentle hills, water falls as well as some fish farms.  It presents an interesting set of views as well as the potential for memorable adventures.

Name: Chin Farm Waterfall
Comment: More of a cascade than a waterfall, however as we are from a very dry, flat and brown part of the world it was a very attractive site for us.The walk from the main road to the waterfall is nothing special but nor is it strenuous. We could not see that the stream was visible from the track until you reach the farm house.Turn left at the sign opposite the Bayview Resort and follow the track to the right for about 15 minutes. Ignore the guard dog compound - they were noisy but locked up and not visible.Turn left at the farm house and across the bridge over the stream that runs to the sea.From here you should be able to follow the sound of the running water from the inland side of the bridge.We were lucky that it had been raining the night before and although the track was boggy (but still passable) the cascades were flowing freely. We spent an enjoyable interlude for an hour just enjoying nature, the peace and quiet and the sounds and sights of the running, falling water.If you are expecting the larger waterfalls found in other parts of Asia then this is not for you.

Name: Indochine Natural
Comment: We visited today and met Mike, really informative and learnt quite a few things. Can‚Äôt wait to try our products. The price is very affordable. Recommend visiting if your in Penang you won‚Äôt be disappointed

Name: Indochine Natural
Comment: Whilst researching Trip Advisor for things to do on my 9-day visit to Georgetown, Penang. A poster mentioned the really nice patchouli soap they bought from the Indochine Natural shop. I was immediately interested because Natural (unsweetened) Patchouli scented body products and diffusers are so hard to find nowadays! I searched the indochinenatural.com website and found pictures and information on their products; there is a great picture of an old apothecary chest with drawers labelled 'Shampoo', 'Body wash', 'Facewash', 'Soap' and other categories of products available. A description and the purchase price of each product is displayed when one clicks on a drawer!This place immediately became #1 on my list of 'things to do‚Äô in Penang!I was not disappointed with my visit to Indochine Natural at Tanjung Bungah which is a short trip by grab car from Georgetown. I was so lucky to speak to Dr Mike Thair, Co Founder and the person who researches the skin care products and their wonderful plant-based fragrances, he explained that no synthetic ingredients are used in the products they sell. They have quite a range of products and a variety of fragrances including; patchouli, lavender, geranium, lemongrass, a number of spices (cloves, cinnamon, star anise) and litsea, a citron-like fragrance I have never encountered before!I ended up buying patchouli soap, a lovely gift box containing 5 small bottles of face wash, body wash and shampoo. My favourite buy was the Litsea Patchouli Face Wash which I opened yesterday and words can't do justice to the intriguing combination of fragrances and the way they reached my senses in stages and then lingered on my skin long after using the face wash. Now I wish I had bought more, there were individual essential oils too - next time! I want to share my wonderful enlightenment as best I can - it was a "to die for" experience the first time I washed my face using the Litsea Patchouli face wash ‚Äì the fragrances came and went so mysteriously, individually then as a combination - it was unreal - first there was a sharp fresh smell (citrus I think) then there was a totally different, velvety, sultry, deep, dark, cold foresty fragrance which seemed to come from a totally different place - this was patchouli but with added spikes of something I can't describe which gave a different olfactory experience - I felt as if I was in a soothing, dark, green forest - then there was a new, different, smooth fragrance I felt floating all around me, probably litsea and patchouli combined - it was really magical, like being in a different land! Well it was a one-time-only experience, never encountered with subsequent uses of this lovely face wash!

Name: Indochine Natural
Comment: We wondered to Batu Ferringhi and took a look on high-end local residents. Ran into this little shop and chat with owner. Mike has a doctoral degree who studies science, so he definitely know what he is doing when he decided to join the natural ingredient cosmetic stream. Mike offers a wide variety of cosmetics from soap bar, shampoo, cosmetic clay, essential oil etc. Two interesting by products are Tea made with byproduct - olive tea leaves when harvesting olive for the oil, and household cleaner  from recycled cooking oil collected from Halal restaurants. Mike is passionate about customers health and try very hard to make a impact on modern cosmetic industry with his specialized knowledge.

Name: Indochine Natural
Comment: Well we got to try b4 we bought, as the old pharmacy accom in Penang had there product in the bathroom, we just had to go & find it. Walked for klms but worth it, I have also bought & had delivered to aus with no problem

Name: Indochine Natural
Comment: Visited with two kids, it‚Äôs a very good experience. We get to learn how to make soap, the owner Dr. Mike was very patient and generous with his knowledge. I personally find that the ingredients used is very natural. After trying the soap I love the fragrance!!!! üòçüòç

Name: Indochine Natural
Comment: Thanks for the fast delivery & the packaging was professional! The soaps are so natural, value for money, not easy to melt and most importantly they're great for my sensitive skin family. This is why I am still prefer to use Indochine natural soaps compare with many other brands. It is so appreciated that your soaps can keep me continue to love them always. Thank you!

Name: Indochine Natural
Comment: Stumbled over this small outlet where you buy directly from the production. It‚Äôs all organic ingredients in their soaps - and made by hand!!! And the owner himself gave us a thorough description of how they make the soaps and about the oils and scents - of course I ended up buying a lot ;)Used the one soap with lemongrass and turmeric already - wauw! It‚Äôs so soft and nice on the skin. And the whole house now is full of lemongrass scent..Pop by if you‚Äôre in the neighbourhood and have a scentastic experience!

Name: Indochine Natural
Comment: When I passed through their production unit (it's a "shop lot"), a very pleasant scent from inside the building before I get to the retail store. At the retail store, the products are clearly and neatly displayed on the rack. The handmade soap bars with scent (patchouli, star anise and coffee, basil and lemongrass, lemongrass, and clove) are properly kept inside glass desiccator respectively to prevent the scent being degrade and mixed with others. For fragrance free and honey soap bar, they are just displayed as is.There are some other great products too such as face oil, essential oils, body shampoo, liquid face wash etc.The most important is they are truly organic (even the liquid is without any synthetic chemicals). The essential oils, are certified with certificate of analysis.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: Only place in Batu Feringhi worth to go shopping or at least browsing is an old Chinese shop selling delicate handicrafts and batik art, some quite old. Figures carved in bone, small wooden statues, cloissonnee clocks, paintings on glass done from the reverse side and other small curio objects make one wonder if all this will be lost when the craftmen die.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: We by chance met the artist. He's quite a character with lots of stories. That made all the difference, otherwise its largely a big shop of similar things.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: This is more of an antique shop/market. We thought it was an Art Gallery so went inside. There are a lot of the same items that you can purchase, lots of wood carvings, jewellery etc.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: Had a very good time browsing round this gallery - you are given the opportunity to shop for very nice little trinkets around 20 RM to quality art pieces as well (around 20,000 RM). A surprise highlight was the presence of the artist of many of these pieces showing us all the quality works he had done. Worth the time! Bring along your 20,000 RM.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: Lots to see. Prices range from pittance to risk of bankruptcy! This obviously includes the out of this world works of art by Teng and his offsprings. Amazing work. Certainly worth a visit for all art lovers. Tough to choose one even if one could afford them all!

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: We usually have a browse through this Gallery. It is packed full of so many different pieces of local and Malay items. They have some interesting antiques and art works, jewellery and Knick knacks. I usually find a little interesting piece or two to take home as gifts. It's worth a look just take your time.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: Stumbled across this gallery whilst going for a walk. Downstairs is an eclectic range of souvenirs and art works but upstairs is a treasure trove of fine batik works. We had the pleasure of spending over half an hour with Mr Teng getting a personalise tour of his and his fathers works. Worth a visit if you enjoy quality artwork.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: Downstairs is typical art and craft, prints, carvings etc.  However, if you have a spare 15 minutes (or spare AUD$4000) ask to go upstairs to appreciate some seriously beautiful batik art by the family who owns this shop.  No pressure to buy anything (thank goodness) but Mr Teng was very kind, showed us much of his art, books, spoke of his travels and exhibitions abroad.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: Well worth a visit for unique handmade arts and crafts.  A peaceful sanctuary away from the noise and heat outside.  The owners are very talented artists and are very welcoming and a pleasure to spend time talking to.  Please go and enjoy.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: This is a shop with some lovely stuff interspersed with junk. I understand security but being followed every inch of the way was really annoying.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: This gallery has a lot of very nice Asian art and things and also a fabulous collection of batik.  Prices were fair and the quality of the merchandise was good.  We bought a beautiful tapestry, a carving and a mask here..  I would have liked to get a second one but no room in my suitcase.  The owner was very nice and very helpful.  I recommend looking here if you want something nice to take home.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: Something for everyone - from cheap tat that my 8 year old daughter loved to pricier exquisite batik and oil paintings from a family of artists. Statues, wood carvings, jade, paintings, fabric, jewellery - difficult not to find something that you never realised before that you had to have!

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: The Yahong Art Gallery is full of the most interesting items from the far East and also smaller items that will fit the suitcase, all items are of high quality and if you are looking for a quality item to remember your trip this is the place, have visited many times over the past 30 years when we are in Penang

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: The Yahong Art Gallery website advertises that it is open from 10am -10 pm. Their advertisement in a tourist brochure gives the same hours of opening. There is no mention of any days on which it is closed.  We double-checked with our hotel who said the Gallery should be open prior to our visit at 11:15 am on Sunday, 15th May, 2016. When we arrived the doors were firmly padlocked shut. On returning an hour later, they were still firmly closed at 12:15 am.In addition, there was no mention of their opening times on their building. This whole experience was very frustrating.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: My husband and I were grateful that we dropped by. There was plenty to see, in all price ranges. Great prints, porcelain, metalware and jewellery. They also wrapped our purchases very, very well.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: A great collection of quality art and crafts that may not be at the night market bargain prices but you get what you pay for.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: Downstairs is filled with the usual tourist souvenir rubbish - some of it quite expensive. But if you can attract the attention of the artist - the man who frequents the shop/gallery  - he can show you the impressive batik cre.ations that he, his brother and his famous father have on show

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: This is one of these stores that runs the gamut from standard tourist fare all the way up to some very fine and expensive art.  It is quite vast and has all different kinds of work.  I found some interesting carved wood and carbon items that I hadn't seen elsewhere.  No doubt the prices are fixed and higher than on the street, but judging money for value is pretty subjective and difficult.  I was satisfied to pay the asking price for my purchases.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: Wasn't part of plan to visit the art gallery, decided to pop in anyway since we are just across the road having lunch. It was a awesome experience. So rich in history, intriguing batik art and a friendly owner/artist.For that hour, I felt just like an art connoisseur, appreciating the original art that are hidden away from the public eye.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: We were eating across the street over looking this art gallery. Made a note to stop by have a look after our meal. Thinking we would only run by some art.. But we found out there is so much  more going on in this modest looking gallery. There were tons of beautiful art batik... Exquisite work of art on batik! Lots of beautiful antiques too. The uncle who showed us around.. Is an artist himself. He ran us through much  of his father's art work and himself over the years. Very much  history told... If you enjoy history.  Really enjoyed our tour and a few souvenirs from here. I highly recommend this place for art lovers.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: You could easily spend a few hours in here as this gallery has everything from earring to pictures to furniture etc etc.  A fine selection of local goods and more.  Well worth a visit.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: This is a strange and interesting gallery. It is full of the sort of things you imagine you will find in George Town, but you never can. If you like "collectables" it is the place for you.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: If you're looking for souvenirs of Penang/Malaysia then this is the place to go.  The owner will give you a private showing of his own art work.  It's very interesting.  It's about a 20mins walk from the Rasa Sayang.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: Located in Batu Ferringhi across from the Parkroyal Hotel. this art gallery showcases the batik prints and private collection of the owner and his family. Be sure to catch the batik demonstration when you are here.. Pewter products, silverware, Sarawak pottery and batik apparels are also on sale here. Worth a visit if you are passing through the area.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: beautiful artwork. the owner (Theng) will walk you through and explain his masterpieces. he has wonderful stories. There is a few pieces which is not for sale; his dad's collections. this place is well worth a visit even if you aren't looking to purchase. One of Penang's finest family of artists.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: Although this gallery contains a lot of tourist "tat", if you are lucky the owner of the gallery will take you to the private area at the rear and show you the original art works by his father and brother, as well as his own, and entertain you with their history.

Name: Yahong Art Gallery
Comment: Five minutes should be enough.This is a gift shop that sells second hand brick-a-brack, furniture and souvenirs. Some interesting furniture is on display. Some are genuine antiques. Some pieces are one off, hand made designs. Certainly. But on the whole, this is a gift shop.Why did I bother reviewing this?

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: All very good experience, traditional market place with hawker food restaurant adjoining.Well worth a visit

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: It looks awful, it might put you off entering but please take the plunge. The food is served at a dozen or so different outlets...some savoury, some sweet, some just juices...fresh juices of every kind. Make your choice, place your order and it‚Äôll be brought straight to you freshly cooked. The chicken satay was fabulous and the prawn & noodles was sublime...and all for between 8-15 Ringgits. We keep going back. I recommend it. Just across the road from Copthorne Orchid.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: This market was very average especially that it only operates on Tuesday nights. You would expect more from a weekly market.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: we stayed in Penang for three weeks and went to the markets every Tuesday. we loved the freshness of the food , fruit and most of all veggies. it was vibrant , great smells from the hawker stalls and a Durian stall that sells the best Durians. we would spend hours walking around and people watching. we enjoyed the freshly cooked corn, Durian, mangosteens, rambutans,  mangoes, guavas that we bought to take back to the hotel. not the Durian as we ate it at the market or they might kick us out of the hotel if we take it back. it smells a little:(

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Great local weekly night market.  So many choices, great value,  seems very local.  Will go back.  Not to hig

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Were recommended this market by people staying in our hotel. Small local market, chaotic car activity with queues on people arriving and trying to park. Some good food stalls doing all sortsof snack food. We picked through several stalls for dinner. There are some other stalls‚Ä¶

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: We visited this local Tuesday market and bought mangoes, jackfruits and other knickknacks. Value for money and fruits very fresh and tasty.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: This market offers a wide variety of hawker food in addition to the traditional wet market stalls selling vegetables , meat , fish and other perishable food.  The place is crowded in the morning from 6 am to 10 am with people going there for marketing and breakfast. A good place‚Ä¶

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: You can get any kind of produce you want in the mornings and early afternoons, from vegetables to dried goods. There's also a bustling food court that covers Indian, Chinese, and Malay cuisines at very low prices - they even have a couple of vegetarian stalls. On Tuesday‚Ä¶

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: This market is amazing as it has most of the items even though it‚Äôs a small market. There‚Äôs all kind of food available. There‚Äôs also dry and wet market as well. Parking is ok. It gets kind of busy about 9am so it‚Äôs better to come by earlier.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Only open on Tuesdays. Fairly small and not much variety. Food court is OK.Far better to go to Batu Ferrinhi night markets.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: This is a Morning Wet MarketYou can get Vegetables , Fish and Meat hereThe Food Court to the Left sells a variety of Hawker Fare and Penang Delights such as Char Koay Teow , Hokkien Mee , etcetera Fruits and Meat Section are at the rear Prices can be said as reasonable Used to be cheap eats here but inflation has crept up Parking is a Need To Wait System Paid Parking is on Mondays to Saturdays , 8 am to 6 pm Sundays are Free Parking

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Market on Tuesday nights.  It has a lot of local fare, as well as the usual imported electronic junk.  Food as everywhere in Penang good and reasonably priced.  Definitely worth a look, especially if your in the are?

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: The food stalls next to the market, open until 12 noon, is an excellent place for breakfast. Lots and lots of stalls selling a wide variety of hawker food. Very clean, very tasty. With something for everyone, our whole family loved having breakfast here.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Every Tuesday from about 6pm this market swings into action.  It has a really great atmosphere, there are lots of stalls, lots if people but it's not crowded.  Best way to get there is by bus, get off at Menara Asus stop and walk around the corner. There are lots of food and drink stalls selling all sorts of goodies from chicken wings and legs, steamed shao mai, deep fried yam and chicken bslls, chicken pau, cooked duck bits of EVERYTHING, popiah, satays, apon, fruit of every kind and drinks including sugar cane juice.  There are also chairs and tables under cover in the building around which the market is located,  along with more food outlets. There are many clothing stands, one selling socks, another shirts, tshirts, skirts, childrens clothing, sandals and thongs etc. etc.  There are other stalls selling phone and tablet/iPad covers etc.  Then there are the hair care ones - clips, combs, brushes, ribbons, all sorts of lotions and potions.  Did I mention belts, handbags, wallets etc?As you can see, there something for everyone, bargain for prices and enjoy yourself.  If it has rained late in the afternoon, or is raining, many of the stall holders will not attend.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Great authentic night mark market, good mix of a lot of locals and a few expats and tourists. A lot of different stores catering for anything and everything you may need with a added bonus of some great food stalls selling Malay/western food which are very cheap. When good‚Ä¶

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: This the place you don't want to missed when you're here. Do drop by to check the market out and enjoy local delicious food and drink.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: This is a great place to grab all kinds of bargains and to eat some fabulous food in the hawkers market.  There is nothing you cannot buy here but the key is haggle haggle haggle

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: So fortunate to be in the Tanjung Bungah area on a Tuesday night when I stumbled upon this night market. There were many food trucks each serving different popular street fare. I quite literally started my food sampling from the start to the end of the street. Best thing was my‚Ä¶

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Every Tuesday evening "the north Penang population" cruises to this colorful evening market. You find cheap China electronic gadgets, al sort of take away local food, fruits, cheap household goods etc. if you have nothing planned go there , stroll around , enjoy some food and watch people. Parking may be an issue. If you can't go on a Tuesday evening visit the daily market from 6am to around 10am. You can take there your local breakfast ( great choice and fantastic tastes) , buy fruits, veggies, fish and meat. It is a fun place and you get an idea how locals do their shopping.üòÄ

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: All is open no shop has Airconditioner. If you like to set outside and try traditional asian food, then this place is for you. If the weather doesn't help, then go to gurney mall. It is a cool place.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: The hawkers here are a picky lot especially on Tuesday nights where there is analternative night market at the same place.When it rains they do not turn up.WSo bestavoid going there in this season.Here there is a bus station and there is only one bus service which takes you to Komtar.There are usually one or two beggars there as well hoping for a coin or two

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: This night market is one of the more popular night markets on Penang Island.   Open every Tuesday evening this market attracts a lot of people and you can find good food, fresh fruits and veggies, as well as other smaller electronics.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Lots of local food, vegetables, fish etc.If you wanna buy some delicious fruit it's the place to be. You can eat here as well, more than enough choice.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: We always come here  local food well cooked would not miss it. Lots of local people come here can not understand negative comments. Don't be put off come and enjoy.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Every Tuesday night the market area runs as a night market. Crowds flock in to taste the food and shop.Personally, I would not bother going with the intent of shopping. Nothing new to see from that perspective. But, the food and snacks are well worth going for. All around the outside of the market building are food stalls selling delicious local snacks. We really enjoyed eating our way around the market. Well worth planning a visit here into your schedule.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: A great place for a local breakfast. Bustling, friendly atmosphere. Lots of cheap household things, clothes. Merchants not English speaking but can make themselves understood. Don't be afraid to haggle ! Cheaper than Batu Feringghi Nite Market.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Not that great a night market its almost the same during the day market except bit cooler during the day.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: For an Indian traveler, the market is what you normally get in the streets and bylanes of Mumbai, Pune or Delhi.The quality of the shirts, cables, artifacts, shoes, bags all you get roughly at the same price in India.It is all imported from China!!

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Good local wet market to buy fresh food. Tuesday night market is very popular. Go early around 6 pm to get a parking place. Location of this market is along Jalan Tanjung Bungah, near the bus termnal.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Note: The correct location is behind the back of the bus terminal. Look in google maps for Pasar & Kompleks Makan Tanjung Bungah instead of following the location provided by tripadvisor. This night market only operates on tuesday and if there is prolonged heavy rain for than an hour most stalls will close early.Open from 6.30pm to 10pm or till late.Generally a local night market with no tourists trap around... great food but little shopping around.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Tuesday night is pasar malam  night (night market), food stalls, clothes, housewares, phone accessories and some modern food trucks. Lots of local food.Locals and foreigners are there for good bargains

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Not a tourist trap like Batu Ferrenghi ...and has a lot of great food. Not a great food court .. there Batu Ferrenghi wins. But on a Tuesday a good place to get some stuff you need.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Get your small pack of nasi lemak with the choice of anchovies, beef, chicken,cockles and squid in the morning. Its cheap and taste good!

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Love this market as its my regular place for marketing,  breakfast and the night market on every Tuesday. Parking might be a little bit difficult on weekends. This place was renovated last year and has a bright new look now. There is a number of clean stalls that serves very‚Ä¶

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: This market is well-equipped with many stalls that sell seafood, chicken meat and vegetables.  You can find eggs,  flowers and fresh tofus too.  However,  they don't sell any beef or mutton. Parking can be a challenge, especially during the weekends.  However,  if you are into‚Ä¶

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: The morning market is open daily.  We visited the night market which is only open on a Tuesday. There are pushcart stalls selling penang food, snacks, ice cream etc. Some stalls at the food centre are also opened.   The must-try food:  1) hot, fluffy, soft freshly steamed buns‚Ä¶

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: The dry part of the market consists of food stalls like noodles, fried kuayteow, roti canai, nasi lemak.. in fact you can find almost any local breakfast under one roof. Parking is relatively easy and located along Tanjung Bungah. Prices are reasonable as well. You can also find‚Ä¶

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: This one is more local and not so overly touristic even you can find here the same cheap items as every where else. But the food stalls are to recommend - good and tasty and very cheap food.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: The market sells all kinds of things, beside the market also has many stalls selling local food.  There is another row of shops opposite the market selling local food too.  I like the hokkien noodles, it is very nice and cheap too.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Every Tuesday night, there will be a night market starting from 7pm. The place will be lined with food stalls on both sides. Also selling the usual night market items

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Very busy, very cultural with wonderful smells of cooking food and origional items to buy. Haggeling is part of the culture and I love it,  The stall holders all want you to bnuy their ware and the many voices just make your holiday.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: We were at the market practically every morning, either buying fruit or eating breakfast or drink coconut water.  The variety of fruits and flowers and the freshness of them takes to back there. There are a couple of Coffee Houses, very deceptive as you get much much more than what the name suggests. The hot white coffee is amazing. You can try the barley water, though I didn't like it much. The main reason we kept going back was for the food. They are opened only until 1pm. So you can do a breakfast or brunch. And you don't get tired eating all that food. In my one week that I was in Penang, I must have had breakfast at least 5 times there. The chicken porridge is yum, so are the pork buns, or the chicken rice, or soupy noodles. You can practically try a new dish everyday. And then end the meal with sweet coconut water. The chap selling the coconuts is outside the market. One of the coffee houses is at the market place and the other is just outside called Kedai Kopi Sin Lee Hin. Both are great. Every Tuesday night there is a night market here, which is very average. You might get a few nick-nacks, hair clips, some basic cane stuff but expect too much out of it. It's nice to just see the place though. Loved the entire experience of the market, chilled and easy going.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: A local market, visit if you are in the vicinity. Mingle with crowd and savour the local specialties. Items sold are nearly the same everywhere but with local flavour thrown in.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Having recently traveled through many cities on our holiday, I found the markets were selling the same cheap stuff everywhere. The exception was Singapore which was flooded with Chinese New Year product.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Great place to visit, lots of variety and food.Sellers in the area very friendly also, highly recommend a visit.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: The night we went it was raining very heavily and most stalls were closed. We went with the hotel shuttle and there was not much we can do except to go find another place for dinner.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: A wide variety of goods available both locally made and or produced as eel as the usual "made in china" products ! on site cooked snacks and delicacies are excellent

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: This is a local night market or known as pasar malam. Located near the Tanjung Bungah Bus Station. Lots of local food to choose and try. This is more for the local people rather than for tourists. But you can see and try what the local people enjoy as their food. Price is not mark up for food as this market served more for the locals.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: This is worth the visit, a great place to wander around at your leisure and at the conclusion sit down and from the unrestricted bill of fare, have a glorious inexpensive meal of you choice.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Almost similar to Petaling Street in Kuala Lumpur. But Tanjung Bungah market only operating at night. They sell many variety of fake & second (lower) graded items like handbag & watches. If you looking for souvenir to bring home, here is the place. They sell t-shirt, fridge magnet, key chain and many more. You also can bargain for the best price. There are a lot of massage centres nearby this area. Get your foot reflexology massage after you done with your shopping.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: These markets occur at the Bus Depot in Tanjong Bungah every Tuesday night and a gret place to find a huge variety of food and nic nacs for a minimal amount. A great couple of hours entertaniment

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: is a local "wet market" but rather expensive for tourists/expats/foreigners! interesting to walk thru but buying is once and never again! they systematically overcharge foreigners/expats/tourists big time!

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: If you are in Penang (Tanjong Bungah) any night - go to the Pasa Malum (Night Markets) and there is a wide range of trinkets / clothes and lots of food. Boy is there a range of different types of food from curries / corn on the cob / cakes etc.A must see when in Penang

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: This was the highlight of our 3-week stay in Tanjung Tokong, and we visited the night market two Tuesdays in a row (and the wet market in the morning).  It reminded us of the night market in Melacca, which we enjoyed very much.Shiendig's suggestions (below) were very helpful.-We loved the deep-fried flatfish(halibut?), prawns and tomato rice (you can choose between plain rice and tomato rice) at Nasi Melayu.  We got there at 6pm and it was already packed and the prawn was almost gone!  (We weren't impressed with other kinds of fish, squid or chicken liver.)-The siew mai at the steamed bun stall was great.  The chicken sticky rice might be the best chicken sticky rice we've ever had.-We're big lovers of Appam, which is hard to find. We were grateful the vendor was there even on a rainy day (60c/pc)  -Rambutan at the fruit stall (we went to the front one by mistake) was the best and cheapest (RM4/kg.  RM7 at the morning wet market; RM8 at the vendor across from Tesco; RM5-6 at the vendors across from the Cove sell RM5-6.)After we discovered this wet market (there's also a small one in Tanjung Tokong), we never bought veggies or fruit at Tesco.The reviewer who complained that half the stalls were closed probably doesn't understand the system--some vendors are open only for breakfast or lunch and don't open for dinner.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Saw the reviews and thought why not, sorry didnt like it one bit half the inside food places weren't open it was the same merchandise every few stalls the toilets were a nightmare, someone could have broken their foot over an open drain hole, a lot of the owners didnt speak english, yes the outside food stalls were plentyful and lots to choose from but that's about it

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Some things have changed, and I would like to contribute the following:DAY MARKET1) Fish Broth Kway Teow Tng--it was a Fish Broth Kway Teow Tng I was recommending, not fish meat. Sorry for the confusion.2) Nasi Melayu--do not miss the home cooked treats at rock bottom prices located at the very beginning of the hawker center nearest to the bus terminal. She serves her food from stainless steel chafing dishes. And she has a newspaper article about her food posted on the wall in her stall. Her chicken rendang is always awesome. 3) Popiah--beside Famous Ah Hock Chicken Rice stall. Try one roll plain, one roll with chili. These rolls are addictive. The uncle is very attentive to his craft, and will ask you what you think of his food. Be honest. :)4) Nonya Economy Rice--smack in the middle of the hawker center, between the Fish Broth Kway Teow Tng and Uncle Robert's Hong Kong Har Cheong Fun is this simple economy rice stall. Her Achar is renown, as is the Salt Fish Curry. Sample her reasonably priced dishes and you will see why scores of aunties swarm her in the early morning with their own to-go containers to load up for their day!NIGHT MARKET--TUESDAYa) Ric's Pork Burgers are no longer there.b) Grilled Squid is also gone (sob).here is a virtual tour if you walked one round:c) Nasi Melayu/Tomato--set up promptly at 6pm on the tables at the mouth of the parking closest to the market (on the way in from the bus terminal it is on the right). Line forms quickly and jumps all the best food, especially the beef rendang. d) Corn Dogs--beside Uncle Bob Chicken. My daughter adores these corn-dogs... (sob)e) Kerabu Beehoon--cross the parking lot and at the corner of the hawker center closest to bus terminal there is a simple table with a mound of pink rice noodle topped with mint, basil and a special zesty sauce. It has a fresh, earthy Thai-Style flavor that is very seductive.f) Gurney Rojak--sets up at about 7pm. Opposite the Kerabu Beehoon, the uncle has mind-bending knife skills. He serves us a fierce Rojak (stinky fruit salad that has alternating  sweet, tangy, hot, fishy flavors. The fruit and vegetables have similarly contrasting squishy, crunchy and crispy bits). This is to date my favorite example of the signature Penang Rojak.g) Steamed Bun Stall--amble to the next corner with the Chinese Temple on the left, and you cannot miss this stall. All the buns have a FLUFFY, yeast roll scent. I love the BBQ Pork, Red Bean and Lotus Paste buns. They also have Siew Mai (prawn dumplings) and Lo Mai Kai--will try that next and report.h) Tapioca Chips RM5--from the Steamed bun stall, this place is just 10m towards the dumpsters, on the right. the Tapioca Chips look just like potato crisps but are more resilient. Great for dips and baked casseroles.i) Lor Bak Stall--walk another 5m little further down from the Tapioca Chip stall and you will see the Lor Bak stall on the left. I skip the mayonnaise and just dip the mildly flavored 5 spice rolls in the chili sauce.j) Hakka Yong Tau Foo--a few meters towards the dumpsters and on the right, opposite the Seafood Char Kway Kak. The uncle sells his assortment of fish balls, fish cake, meat balls and stuffed tofu with a sweet fermented bean sauce and fiery chili sauce. RM3 for a simple assortment of about 8 pieces (?). He is not always there, but I look for him each time.k) Kachang Puteh (assorted freid peas, beans, nuts)--the next stall on the left just before the dumpsters sells muruku (lentil flour snacks spiced with curry powder), steamed chick peas (garbanzo beans) and fried broad beans, peanuts, chick peas, peas, etc. My favorite are the fried vada (lentil balls)--both kinds 3 for RM2. One looks like a tiny golden brown bagel/doughnut and the other a dark brown coarse lentil ball.l) Fruit Stalls--round the corner from the dumpsters are the 2 fruit stalls that consistently sells some of the best apples, oranges, plums and other fruit (at prices lower than cold Storage). I particularly like the Pink Lady Apples and little California Oranges. Frequent these stalls regularly and the owners will make honest recommendations about fruit that are particularly good.m) PUBLIC RESTROOMSThey exist at this market, but are perpetually wet and are often smelly. Bring your own toilet paper and sense of humor.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Went to the Tuesday night markets.   Was so looking forward to it.   But unfortunately as it had been raining quite heavenly all day, not many stalls were open.   Not many of the food stalls were open.    Quiet night, as not many people around.Will definitely go on our trip to Penang, and hopefully it wont be raining.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Aplenty to eat for breakfast, ranging from Chinese, Malay to Indian food and even vegetarian dishes and western set breakfast as well. There is hawkers selling clothes, knick knacks, household wares and etc. Quite packed during public holidays and weekends, so go early to avoid disappointment. The same goes for the parking as well as quite limited at times. During the afternoon, there is a couple of stalls selling food (the famous Hock Chicken Rice is one of them) while most will be closed.Highlight is on Tues night - the night market. You will have to park further away and walk to the night market.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Lots of nick nacky stuff. heaps of sunglasses,watches, hand bags etc,etc. All real too (NOT !!!!!) But keep an open mind and remember what you are really buying. It's a bit of fun and some of the stuff isn't bad for what you pay.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: I am from Penang but now living elsewhere.  So whenever am back to my hometown I would visit this market in the morning. Love the Nasi Lemak, Char kuey Kark and Char Mee Sua there and if you were to go there in on Saturday morning, don't ever missed out the stall selling rice and ready dishes.  It's next to the Hong Kong Chee cheong fun stall.  I have to go there early on Saturday morning (one of the owners, mentioned they only sell it on Saturday) as they normally run out of it pretty fast. The crunchiness of the vegetable and the sweet and fragrant achar gravy added on with sesame make me want more each time. If I am not wrong the dishes they sell mostly are Nyonya Dishes.Looking forward to my next visit for more Penang hawkers food.  visit for more Penang food.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: After scouring Queen Street and perusing some of the Batu Ferringhi Night Market options, my wife really likes the batiks and other fabrics and clothes in the short row of stalls beside the egg seller in the wet market. She says that the quality is good and the prices low.In addition, we have been loving the tart apple pies (sometimes special order), and puffy chicken pies from the stall in the middle of the hawker center, next to the Kway Teow Soup. The couple is very friendly and hospitable!Finally, we noticed a grilled dried squid stall last night at the Tuesday Night Market. They were on the right at the entrance walking to the market from the bus terminal. It has been a long time since I had dried squid that was not cardboard, grilled on a charcoal fire, pressed and stretched to double/triple length to tenderize the flesh, and then grilled again for caramelization and flavor! All for RM6 for a larger squid that was about a foot long. You will be drooling during the 10 minute wait, but this is a craft from the past and I love this stuff!

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: the local inhabitants and those on holiady in nearby apartments require every day. Much more atmospheric than the nearby Tesco superstore !! Open every morning and twice the size every Tuesday evening .....definitely worth visiting ........try local snacks, get a drink, buy super fresh fruit ? veg and even orchid plants and live snakes. We all found something worth buying. An hour passes very swiftly going around this very colourful local haunt.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: I loved this night market and not just because there's not much else to do.. But because it had alot of good quality knock-offs and souvenirs. Remember to bargain and walk away if you don't get the price you want

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: We live in this neighborhood, so we have become quite familiar with this market.We buy our vegetables, coconut cream, eggs and chicken at this wet market in the mornings. Come before 9am to beat the crowd, and also have breakfast at the hawker stalls next to it.Stalls that are noteworthy include:Hong Kong Prawn Cheong Fun and Fried Sesame BallsFish Kway Teow ThngThosaiThe best apple and chicken pie in the neighborhoodChicken congeeOutstanding hakka noodles.On Tuesday Nights, the area transforms into a night bazaar. The best steamed buns feature on the corner near the temple, and a great gurney Rojak stall shows up at about 7pm. We buy our fruit from the 2 vendors at the back near the dumpsters. They give consistently the best quality apples and oranges. Ask them what they recommend. Ric also has the best pork burgers that taste bacon like! At 6pm, a Nasi Melayu stall opens in the parking lot and a flurry of people will swarming. No wonder since they have the best beef rendang ever.If you drive, get there before 5:45pm to find a parking space or you will have to get creative!

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Tanjung Bungah Market is the biggest wet market on the northern part of Penang Island. It serves the community on the tourist belt, which is becoming more and more developed as condominiums and upmarket apartment blocks are constructed in the area. It is part of the bus interchange of Tanjung Bungah. The market is located off the main road behind the Geok San Soo Temple. However you don't have to walk in, if you are taking the bus, as the Tanjung Bungah bus terminal is at the same location as the market.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Nice way to end the evening after a good meal browsing the markets

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: Bargain the price to get good deals for souvenirs. There are also other stuffs that they sell along the road.

Name: Tanjung Bungah Market
Comment: tanjung bungah markets operate on a tuesday night.they are truely local with plenty of fresh food and of course a food hall for meals.getting there is easy if you are stay in the area if not the bus will drop you off and the service is quite good.the stall holders are for more friendlier than those down at the beach night markets.you can buy much the things here at better prices .the mozzies can some times be a problem so a spray of insect repellant is a good idea.the stall holders will go out of their way to help tourist and unlike the beach markets do not hassle you to buy.it is in my opinion a better market place.as you leave the markets on the left hand side is a small shopping complex with a great chinese food outlet one of the best very few westerners have discovered it.also inthe same complex in the front on the far end is a good laundry and dry cleaners not the one near the chinese food hall you will pay to much with them.you will not be sorry if you spend some time or stay at tanjung bungah the ideal hotel is the copthorne orchid book a terrace room it is well worth the stay.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Very good trekking, I decided to go to the Kerachut Beach both ways - I did not want to pay for expensive boat trips. I started early in the morning (7:30) because I had only limited time for trekking and also wanted to avoid crowds. The trail was easy with a few very steep parts - take good shoes, no flip-flops. It took cca 75 min to go there (I am average but experienced trekker), the way back was much faster - cca 60 min. But during going back I met hundreds of tourists in the opposite directions and had to often wait until big groups (20-30 people) pass by due to narrow paths. I was lucky that I started early in the morning and was almost alone on the beach. The weekend is not a good time for visiting this park - the crowds of tourists may negatively influence your experience. But the beach is nice and trekking in the jungle is very good experience. Unluckily I did not see any turtles because the facility on the beach opens at 10am and I did not have enough time to stay longer. I saw monkeys and an otter instead.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: As I visited here 7 years before, this time I just bring my friend to here to have some photos and stay only 1 hours. Both of us have no time to hike inside to the beach. I find here more family come than 7 years ago. Sign name at receiption and get a pass to hike inside.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: We did a good 2 hour walk through the forest and saw some lovely birds etc . It's easy walking . We had hoped to swim on arrival at a lovely beach but there were warning signs about jelly fish. We got a boat back to the village and then caught a bus back to town. A good day.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: In a way I am quite reluctant to share about this attraction, Turtle Beach (Pantai Kerachut) in the Penang National Park (or Taman Negara in the Malay language, Bahasa Melayu) as it's probably the only beach left in Penang that is clean and relatively untouched.  To get there you could take a boat or  hike there, about a 1.5 hour hike, on a well-marked trail though difficult in places. We discovered this place by mistake because the place we wanted to visit was actually Monkey Beach but on that day the trail to reach it was closed due to a landslide. The park opens at 8 am and entrance to the park is free. Bring your own water as Turtle beach is a conservation area so there are no vendors there (thank goodness). If you wear proper walking shoes the walk is pleasant and manageable. You are walking through the forests so it's shady for the most part. When you reach the last 20 minutes of the trail you have the option of taking the shorter but steeper drop to the beach or the gentler path that goes behind the Mecromitic Lake and parallel to the beach. So take the gentler track on the return trip if you are walking back. If you choose to take a boat back to the park entrance, do book the boat before you set off on your track. The boat fare is about 90Rm per boat (not per passenger) per trip. Of course, we walked back.  Please bring your trash out with you.No swimming is allowed on the beach. There is a small turtle sanctuary (nothing to shout about). Definitely worth a visit - you will need a whole morning but you can reward yourself with a nice lunch at one of the restaurants near the entrance to the park (you have choice of Malay or Chinese ones that serve western dishes as well)

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Our hike to Turtle Beach in Penang National Park blew our expectations out of the water.   First, this hike is not for anyone who is out of shape or who can't climb a fairly steep incline, as it is completely unpaved trails with lots of steep hills.  If you're willing to put in the work in Penang's hot temperatures, the jungle scenery is well worth it!  You'll pass over bridges, streams, and be greeted by Turtle Beach as the trail opens to the sea.  The National Park is a bit out of town, but taking a taxi or Grab from Georgetown is also a great way to see some of the landscape in between.   Well worth the trip to escape the city for the day- highly recommend!

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Very nice place. We made the walk into this park to the Turtle Beach (the walk to Monkey Beach was closed). Easy walk where you can see monkeys (dusty leaf monkeys) and monitor lezards for example.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: We visited the park today. Took the easier coastal path to walk along but this was difficult in places were the path was steep and there were boulders and large tree routes to climb over. Really nice beaches along the coast with no one on them. Good sightings of the monkeys along the route. Took a taxi there cost 30 ringgits the bus back cost 1.5 ringitts each

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Great trek through National Park to Turtle  beach! Friendly chat with park ranger. 40 RM for boat around to Monkey beach! Great swimming at Monkey beach and local lunch at BBQ!  Bit of interaction with local monkey population!!

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: We got the 101 bus from the Komptar bus station which took about an hour and cost 6.80 RM each.  The bus stops right outside the park.  We walked all the way to turtle beach.  It took about 90 minutes.  It's very steep and quite hard going in places, but there are lovely straight bits where it is shaded and beautiful.  We walked there and back, though we could have got a boat back from the beach.  The beach is lovely, though swimming wasn't no allowed when we were there.  There wasn't much to see at the turtle conservation place.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: We wanted to hike to Monkey Beach but were told that the trail was closed due to a fallen treeü§î. We were advised by the park ranger to take a boat instead.Since we really wanted to do the hike, we ended up hiking to Kerachut Beach (can be done in 1.5hrs or less) and taking a one way boat back to the park entrance. It was a pretty easy hike with clearly marked trail. We met with some long-tailed macaques on our way in. Kerachut Beach was quite nice. We rested for a bit by the rocks before taking a boat back. The boat ride was a bit bumpy and we had to walk on a rickety jetty upon arrival at the entrance which was pretty fun! Overall, a clean national park.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: We took rental motorcycle to go the National Park. The entrance is free but we need to register at the Ranger check point. They have a lot trekking trails and camping sites. We took trail B which takes approximate 45 minutes to reach. We enjoyed trekking along the seaside during the evening breeze. It was calming and relaxing trekking experience.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Great hiking from national park to tutle beach, its took 1h15min to turtle beach and there has a turtle sentury at the end of the beach from turtle beach we took a boat went to monkey beach

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: We arrived about 11am and as some other reviews have pointed out the boat operators will come up and tell you the track to Monkey Beach is closed. We kinda took that as a challenge and sure enough you can walk to monkey beach with minimal effort. The track  isn't paved and there are some wooden bridges with broken planks etc, but if you're anyway interested in hiking its not a major challenge. Approx 4km start to finish. At the beach theres a few huts where you can buy a beer or get some bbq food. It's well worth the effort and if you don't fancy the walk back the boats come and go all the time so just ask of them and you can pay you go back.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Very easy to get the bus from Batu Ferringhi to the National Park and only RM2 each to get there.We walked out to Pantai Keracut (Turtle Beach) from the National Park Entrance. Excellent hiking through rainforest. The track isn't paved and does require some scrambling (easy and part of the fun!). There are monkeys in the trees along the walking track. The secluded beach at Pantai Keracut is well worth the walk. This is a turtle nesting beach and there is a Turtle Conservation Sanctuary here too. They had turtles of various ages to see and information about the turtles. We were lucky enough to see turtle tracks up the beach from the evening before/early that morning. On the walk back we saw an Asian Water Monitor scroll across the track. A great day out exploring the island!Also note that walk to Monkey Beach is currently closed due to a landslide on the walking track. You are able to get a boat to Monkey beach if you want to visit it.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: The hike to the turtle beach is great, we went there before noon and that was something we would recommend everyone. We had a local showing us around and even tho it doesn‚Äôt matter at wat time of the day you hike because almost everything is in the shade, the earlier you the More you have the Place for your own. The Monkey beach was ok but a bit dirty.Definitely take a boot from the turtle beach to the monkey beach, it‚Äôs 10 MYR and it‚Äôs great. We had some rough waves so it was a very existing ride (at least for us who like a shaky boat).

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Great day out for the entire family.  You can take the boat service in 2 directions to the nearby beaches or walk 1 direction and boat the other.A 1 direction walk would suit families or elderly.  Both directions takes about 3 hours reasonably straightforward hiking.  So depending on level of fitness really.The virgin forest is stunning.  Immersive sounds and smells with an opportunity to see the local wildlife.The entry is free.  You need to do a registration at the office and they ask for passport number.  So photograph your passport with your phone, so no need to worry about carrying your passport.Pack some sun screen, a hat and a camera and of you pop on the well marked trail.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: My wife and I did the Turtle Beach hike both ways one afternoon and I did half of it again on my own early on another morning. It's strenuous in a few places, inc. a long, steep climb at the start, but it's totally worth the experience. Good shoes are recommended but my wife was fine in flip-flops! Just take it slowly and carry lots of water.  (They also sell large bottles at Turtle Beach for RM4).The Buddhist quote "It's better to travel well than to arrive" applies though - most of the wildlife is out of sight in the trees but there is a constant soundscape of insects, frogs, birds, and branches swaying in the wind high above you. Unless you're really lucky in your timing, you won't see any turtles at the beach except a few babies in one tank and a couple of juveniles in two others.Re: the review just below that says "not much opens in Penang before 10:30-11am, including the national park", the booth where you officially register to go in (at no charge) opens at 8am but you can go in beforehand if you want. The boat trip sellers outside (their stalls misleadingly labelled as "information") also start opening around 8.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: We loved this park. Perhaps because we were staying in Georgetown and it felt like a really developed city - we were expecting it to be a bit smaller. So we needed to get away to nature and so the park was fantastic. Having read all the tips about the trails being closed, we decided to walk straight to MOnkey Beach anyway. We checked with the guides outside and they said it's for our own risk and responsibility. It took us about 1.15min and the trail is very interesting, full of raw nature. Due to the landslides some parts of the walkways or bridges were quite touch to cross (missing wooden steps etc) but overall rather easy to manage. The entire park could do with some better maintenance as there were missing steps all throughout, not just within the 'closed' trail. Visitors should be charged at least a symbolic USD 1-2 to help them with this. Ayway, the Monkey Beach was fantastic - easy to swim with beautiful sand and surroundings. Were stayed there all afternoon and in fact we even rented a tent-hut for USD 15 to stay overnight. It was great to be able to feel like the only visitors on the beach. We bought chinese noodle soup in the only 'shop' there which we had for dinner.   We also later in the afternoon went up the lighthouse which was good, although the view is not outstanding. Definitely recommended for the nature lovers!

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Been to Penang countless times before but somehow never visited this National Park. Had a free morning of sorts on my last day in Penang on this trip and so I decided (quite at the last minute) to take a morning hike there as the weather was predicted to be sunny and beautiful that day. No regrets at all about my decision to go on this trek... it was absolutely the correct decision and it turned out to be a fantastic experience for me.  The walk was an easy and leisurely one overall,  and only slightly strenuous at parts. It was all in a very enjoyable 1.5 to 2 hour hike to Turtle Beach through dense tropical jungle and passing quite magnificent vistas along the way. The end reward was a beautiful deserted beach all to ourselves ( the tourists coming in by boat had not arrived yet) and there was an isolated government turtle sanctuary there open to all to visit for free. Highly recommended if you have not visited this part of Penang before. We took a boat back to save time and to enjoy a different sort of scenery : we passed some beautiful rocky coastlines on the way back to the park entrance through the slightly choppy waters. A very worthwhile and memorable trip in my opinion.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: We took grab to the main gate, easy and cost effective. Was a typical hot day 33C so took plenty of water I would also advice sunscreen and bug spray due to a number of hungry mosquitoes that live in the woods. Within 10 minutes walk the pave road ends and you are on well worn paths. The road braches ( and is signposted) left to turtle Beach etc and right to monkey beach. We went right, and walked another kilometer before stopping on a lovely beach for pictures and to mop the stinging sweat that was running like a river into my eyes causing almost total blindness. We decided at this point to head back and take the boat, part laziness and part wanting to see more than one beach.The boat was around 170 rinngit, you could get cheaper but I wasn't for sharing. The walk along the jetty was beyond frightening, a good 100 meter's on rotting planks which felt like they were going to snap on every step as they creaked and moved.This was just a warm up for the boat, the captain was a wild eyed individual with a large maniacal grin, which I realized after departure was caused by the G force of the rocket propelled vessel. My spine and backside was tested like a shock absorber as we bounced across the sea like a skimmed stone, and wobbly kneed we arrived at Turtle beach. I was not impressed with turtle Beach, not much to see and the lake at the far end was non existent, possibly because it was the wrong time of year but this wasn't explained when we looked at beautiful pictures from the boat rental company.After an hour the maniacal captain returned and bounced us round to Monkey beach. Now I like Monkeys, they remind me of very naughty children and Monkey beach was full of them. We sat in a shack that served cold beer and coconuts we had one of each and within seconds we had a gang of little mischievous monkey friends. A firm grip was required on the coconut as naughty monkeys would remove it from you possession in the blink of an eye.  Afer an hour our captain appeared and it was another high speed bumming back to the pier of death, it is worth noting that parts of his boat fell of during the trip and piecies of metal bounced in the bottom of the boat as we skimmed the sea. Overall a 10 out of 10 experience, beautiful landscape with more excitement than any rollercoaster could provide with the added bonus of monkeys.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: One thing to note is not much opens in Penang before 10:30-11am, including the national park. When we arrived we were told there was a landslide on the track to Monkey Beach and we could not walk there and we had to get a boat, we weren‚Äôt sure whether this was true but chose to get the boat anyhow so we could see Monkey Beach and Turtle beach. The boat is 90-100MR per boat, regardless of number of people, so try and team up with some people to make it cheaper. We were also told the suspension bridge was closed, again, didn‚Äôt check, so unsure if this is true. We stopped at Monkey beach and walked up to the lighthouse, the lighthouse was not worth the effort but we saw what was maybe a lemur and that was pretty cool, Monkey beach itself is cool with its little shacks and monkeys all around, would recommend. We were Then dropped at turtle beach and then walked back, its a nice walk and in the heat a decent effort with a few up hills. Overall, I wouldn‚Äôt go out of my way to do this, we did it as we kind of had an extra day to use up. Cheers!

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Read about this on Trip-advisor before we left to visit the National Park.We ignored all the outdoor kiosks and entered directly into the main gate of the park and the kiosk.Maybe a bit more research on my part would have been better, our age group went from 40, 60 & 70. The older 2 bailed out after 150 metres, 1 x 60 year old bailed out after 250 metres and the last of us 3 carried on. The trek we took was to turtle bay, the first 50 mins or so was walking on extremely rough terrain in temperatures in excessive of 35cMy advice, take trainers or good walking shoes, plenty of water and unless reasonable fit and strong, don‚Äôt attempt it!That said it was a fantastic hike.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Nice simple trail to the Turtle Beach which is quiet but small and boring. Took the speedboat from Turtle Beach to the Sg entrance via Monkey Beach, it was an exciting ride through very choppy waters but Monkey Beach was small, nothing fantastic and very crowded. The best part about the National Park is the trek itself and the beaches could be skipped

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: After the long bus trip to the Penang National Park, we were dismayed to find signs indicating that two of the biggest attractions - the Monkey Beach trail and the Canopy Walk - were closed, apparently since 2017, due to a landslide.Closures due to natural disasters are of course both unfortunate and unavoidable. But the way in which these closures were handled seems poor at best - as some other reviewers suspect, it may even be a scam to goad tourists into taking an overpriced boat ride to a non-existent"island".¬†According to the signs announcing the closure, this information is posted on the official Penang National Park website.
