This surprised me, given that I'd spent quite a bit of time researching trail maps, the registration procedure etc. in advance, and hadn't seen anything mentioning closures. As it turned out, the official-looking website I had assumed was the Penang National Park site was not at all. TripAdvisor won't let me share the official web address (even though it's a governmental, not commercial site) but it has "wildlife" in the URL and is not exactly obvious, nor something that pops up immediately when you do a search (at least in English).¬†As it turns out though, visiting the correct site made little difference. On the mobile site, I couldn't find a way to access an English version, but neither did there seem to be any obvious notices of closures in Malay. At home, I checked the desktop version, and lo and behold, there is English available if you click the little UK flag at the top. Then, if you select "Penang National Park" from the "Public" menu, you will be taken to an information page... which doesn't mention the Monkey Beach trail closure at all. There is no notice next to the hiking activites. The only closure listed is a note that the canopy walkway is "temporarily closed for maintenance", but given the URL suggests this page was created in 2016, and it doesn't seem to have been updated since, it appears that "temporarily" might mean three years or more!¬†Clearly a better job could be done of alerting visitors to these closures before they make the trip to the park. But other reviewers have voiced their suspicions that the closures (and their poor communication) may be a scam to goad tourists into taking the expensive boat rides to "Monkey Island", the deceptive name given to a stretch of beach further up the coast more properly known as Monkey Beach. Monkey Beach is surrounded by the National Park but is itself privately owned. The theory is that once tourists have arrived after a long bus trip or expensive taxi ride and discover they have no other option than to take a boat ride because the trail is closed or because they're told it's an island, they'll pay whatever is demanded. After seeing for myself what little effort has been made to alert tourists to these closures before they arrive, and after so long, I share some of these suspicions. It's notable that the Penang Tourist Map, produced by the State Tourism Board, marks the State Museum with three red asterisks and informs visitors that it "is closed for 3 years from 2017", but not only is no such warning given for Teluk Duyung (Monkey Beach), it actually promises "Take on the nature trails and hike all the way up to the pristine beaches of Teluk Duyung, Muka Head, or Pantau Kerachut" which is not possible, and hasn't been since 2017. Why is the museum's closure (from the same year) communicated to visitors, but not the beach's? A lack of communication or deliberate obfuscation seem to be the only possibilities.As disappointing and suspicious as all of this is, tourists who want to experience nature and see some wildlife should not lose hope - the national park, despite the rubbish other reviewers have mentioned (tires, diapers, bottles and cans) is a beautiful place, and you can still have a pleasant walk to USM CEMAC/Teluk Aling (around 2km/40min from the entrance) even if it's not the full hike to the Monkey Beach/Teluk Duyung (which is 3.4km/1.15hr from the entrance).Entrance to the National Park is free, your only obligation is to register before entering (this appears to be solely for data gathering purposes - there was nobody in the booth to check our permit on entry, and  you aren't requested to sign out, so it doesn't seem to be for safety reasons.)Just inside the park is a small beach on which you can see monkeys after just a short walk (around 15min). Check this area before agreeing to an expensive boat ride (past reviewers have said they paid up to 100RM per person, one way, which is the equivalent of $70AUD for a round trip - extremely pricey for what is a very short boat ride, and especially so when you consider the reports of people paying 100RM for a private boat at the entrance, only to have the captain pick up others along the way for only 10RM each.)You may just find you can bypass the expense and the long trek by visiting this much closer, less spoiled beach.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Penang National Park is not taken care of. Beaches are dirty (plastic, cans) and infrastructure is poor. The jetties are rotten. Monkey Beach needs urgent cleaning, the shops there do not take care. Water is trouble. Not worth visiting until the Park authorities take action.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: I‚Äôve been to several national parks and beaches in Malaysia over 4 separate visits to the country. All have been stunningly beautiful and exceptionally run. Penang national park is a very disappointing exception. I always prefer to hike, but was told that the trail has been‚Ä¶

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: My daughter and I had a really good and straightforward trip to Monkey Beach. We got the 101 to last stop. A bloke called Raf approached us about going to Turtle Beach by boat, but said we couldn‚Äôt swim there. I said we just wanted to go to Monkey Beach. Easy. 50RM per person‚Ä¶

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: It should be made clearer that the Canopy walk is closed as is the trail to Monkey Beach. The trail to Turtle beach is over a hours hike and frankly it is disappointing. No swimming due to jellyfish and the sanctuary itself has hardly anything to see. We took a boat to both‚Ä¶

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: A bit of a disappointment as both the Canopy Walk and Monkey Beach were closed off when we visited in October. Maybe it would be prudent for visitors to hold off until the repair work etc...has been completed.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: I agree on previous comments on bad signalization and condition of the pathways. The canopy path was not open on Nov 2019. Lot to do to fix it. Beside this, I really appreciated walking under the trees and reaching the turtle small museum. Taking one path after the other one,‚Ä¶

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: We spent a full day at Penang National Park. If you plan to hike the jungle treks I would suggest that you might have a much more enjoyable experience than if you were to take the "short-cut" by speed-boat. The speed-boat ride was, admittedly, exhilarating, but it brings you to only two stops, i.e. the turtle sanctuary and Monkey Beach. The turtle sanctuary was in fact closed (not full-on turtle season yet) and Monkey Beach was also very quiet (perhaps closed?) due to the public holiday. All-in-all a rather disappointing day-trip. My suggestion is to do most of your exploration by foot and skip the expensive speed boats -- including giving Monkey Beach a miss and avoiding the turtle sanctuary unless you call ahead and make sure that it is turtle season indeed and that turtles will show up to the party. Besides, they come up mainly at night anyway.... The best way to reach the national park is by grab taxi. The public busses are cheap but take too much time.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: A good simple hike for city folks like myself seeking for some adventures. Nothing close to difficult but also not exactly a walk in the park.The boat ride back was nice!Not sure if I would come again as hiking-holiday is personally not my combo, but I appreciate and enjoyed the experience very much.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: I just like to bring to all visitors‚Äô notice that there is a long-running scam, ongoing for many years, at the Penang National Park (PNP) at Telok Bahang. For years and years now, it is reflected to hiking visitors to the PNP that parts of whatever hiking trail, typically to popular Muka Head or Pantai Kerachut, that the trail, or part of the trail is closed. This is to redirect hikers to take the paid boat rides, benefiting the boat operators. I hike frequently at PNP. This is a long-running scam. Every time I go ahead with the hike regardless, the trails are OK, no problem, no obstacles, no impediments. I can hike end-to-end.This scam is very bad for Penang tourism‚Äôs reputation and credibility. Unknowing foreign hikers who travel all the way to Telok Bahang by long bus ride or expensive taxi ride, when told this at PNP site, have no choice but compelled to take the paid boat rides. This is willful deception and cheating. Very bad for Penang‚Äôs tourism reputation.I would suggest that Penang Tourism do an independent investigation on this. Pretend to be a casual foreign tourist. You will find certain trails perpetually closed.I hope clear and firm action can be taken. I am not sure of this, but PNP onsite staff may be (?) in cahoots with the boat operators to mislead hiking visitors. The boat rides are not run by the PNP, but by private operators hovering around the PNP reception building.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Went to the National Park aiming to walk to Monkey Beach, but part of the trail was closed (and has been since late 2017 from what I could work out?) and we would have had to pay to get a boat part of the way, so decided to walk to Turtle Beach instead.The trails are in need of some slight repairs, but nothing too bad, and the trail was clearly marked with maps along the way. Visited the turtle sanctuary at the beach at the end of the walk - the green turtles that are kept there have plenty of space and will be released as soon as they are healthy, however the Hawksbill turtle's area was a little small for my liking, and he was the only one on his own which made me a bit sad. Overall it seemed like a decent place though, which is focused on conservation and not tourists, which is a good thing.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: You can catch the 101 bus from Georgetown for 3.2RM or book a Grab for 26-31RM. I suggest getting there for 8-9am as the heat around 12-3pm is uncomfortable. There‚Äôs lots of information kiosks outside the main gates selling boat trips between Turtle beach, Monkey beach and the port. These are helpful but costly (35-45RM p/p) and you can get by without them, but if you want to do both beaches and relax they save a lot of time. These boat operators claim the monkey beach trail is closed due to and avalanche. This in my opinion is a sales tactic to buy a boat ticket as this would be the only way to visit Monkey Beach. The route is passable and many people used this on our visit, the park office don‚Äôt mention the route is closed. Turtle Beach doesn‚Äôt have any shops, bars or restaurants and is immaculately clean and you cannot swim in the sea.Monkey beach has beach bars where you can grab a drink and lunch. You can also rent jet skis, banana boat and other water sport equipment.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: It's free to visit & only required to registered yourself at the counter before entering the national park. Hiking or renting a boat are available.  Hiking to monkey beach is much more fun than riding boat

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: I did not expect the 'hill' to have a village on top! There's so much to see! I recommend going on the habitat trail! That was the best thing there!

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Certain parts of the trek are closed due to renovation like beach etc but it‚Äôs. A must for trekkers What a unique experience and we carried a stick around just in case some animal sprung around. It‚Äôs like being in wildlife in true sense It‚Äôs all raw and an amazing experience to go for Wear light as it‚Äôs too hot and no water inside . Need to wear sports shoes else u can slip

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: The lady at the restaurant told us that the walking path to monkey beach is not closed even though the official sign said it was closed. She told us that sign is to convince us to take the boat instead. We didn‚Äôt test this out as we wanted to take the boat anyway, but perhaps check the trail (not trust the sign) if you are keen to walk the trail.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: My first time visit to the National Park. Nice jungle filled with nature; flora and fauna. Also home to the wild animals. Spent half a day just to see how the place is like and do assessment for safety hazards before bringing students there for a hike.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Yes you can hire a boat to take you to monkey beach or turtle beach but you would miss so much of the jungle trekking experience.  With 2 daughters who are not the biggest fans of bugs, this is a safe way to do a jungle trek for 4 jungle novices.  The path is clear and it takes 1 hour 20 mins to walk through the jungle to the other side of the island.  You can't swim in the sea here but the sand is golden and the views are unspoilt. There is a small turtle sanctuary here too which is worth a visit.  It is a step back to nature and a complete contrast to the hustle and bustle of Georgetown.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: We chose to walk to turtle beach. Great hike through the forest past beautiful plants, birds and butterflies and accompanied by nature's cricket and bird orchestra. We are reasonably fit and didnt find this trail too challenging. Perhaps not suitable for children under 12, the unwell or the elderly, but all others should be fine. Just wear good shoes and take a lot of water. The reward of turtle beach at the end is more than worth it! It is a stunning and relatively empty paradise and also much nicer, cleaner and quieter than monkey beach where we went to afterwards (see other review)"

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Spent a great day treaking through the park. Started first with a boat trip and then walked through the forest. So pleased we opted to have a guide as he was able to point out all the wildlife and plants. It is hot and very sticky so bring plenty of water. It is a tough track but so worth it !

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Although there is the very reasonably priced 101 bus that takes you to the national park, we took a taxi as much quicker 50RM from Gurney Drive. At the entrance you will be accosted by boat touts, who have various fixed price options to transport you to various beaches. As the track to Monkey Beach is closed from USM, you have to take a boat. We opted to walk to USM (45 minutes in the steaming hot jungle, on a very uneven and poorly maintained track), then boat pick up to Monkey Beach and return to park entrance. For our family of four this was 80RM. The boat picked us up as planned, and it was a fun trip through the waves - we all lived this. Monkey Beach is quite narrow, and ok to sit in the sand and chill for a while. The water isn't very clear, but no jelly fish. No monkeys. We decided not to walk the steep track to the lighthouse. The boat picks you from the pre-arranged spot and takes you back to the park entrance. No taxis around so you'll need to call one or pop into one of the shops and they'll line up one for you - likely an unofficial taxi, but rates are the same. Again, the bus is cheaper if you are happy to wait for one.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Decided to take my 2 young gals treking in the park. Come prepared for a good workout.  The trees provided a shady canopy while the steep ascend and decend certainly made the trek challenging.  There are 2 main treks that leads to the beach and a lighthouse respectively.  You can visit the monkey beach and turtle sanctuary as part of your destination. Be prepared for 1 to 2 hours treking to reach your destination depending on your pace.  It will probably be a whole day affair and go prepared with lots of water.  There are no shops selling water at some of the destinations. If you are exhausted after reaching you destination,  you can take a boat ride back to the pier at the entrance of the park. Boat ride will cost you RM 10, if you have about 8 pax,  if you have less the boat man may charge you more. So,  try to team up with others to get a better rate.  Overall,  i would only recommend it if you are reasonably fit and discourage you if you are unwell.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: If you wanna go to this place, make sure of 2 things. First, check the weather for sure and if it's getting rainy, it's not really worth it in my opinion cause there's almost 1-hour walk through the forest to the turtle beach. Seconed, make sure you're ok to walk for almost an hour (a bit more or less depending on your speed)! It may get a little tyring but we got used to it really soon and really enjoyed the forest walk. Turtle beach is really beautiful but it's not allowed and not safe to swim there. If you wanna swim you're gonna have to take a boat to take you to the monkey beach which we did but I think it wasn't as beautiful as turtle beach and the water didn't seem really clean. If you wanna swim, be careful with the jelly fish cause even though it's allowed to swim there, there are jelly fish there. All and all, I surely enjoyed my time in penang national park and its nature!

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: The adventure never to be taken lightly. This over ambitious unplanned mission to go to the end of the earth to discover a small beach with no one there and for you to claim it all didn‚Äôt come easy. It is tough going up and down and up and down on very many steep slopes. My Apple watch told me that i took about 100 minutes to walk 5 km from entrance to kampi. There were many fallen trees and many broken bridges,  paths , ropes and many years of neglect. Signage was very poor: overall about 3 signs. If you are stuck in there, you are gone. No one will find you.! a litre of water is not enough but you have to carry it: at least 2L. I hike weekly up down 800m+ in about 30 mins last 4 years and walk 5 km daily in preparation for mission like this. It has helped heaps and to kampi you need to train. Nothing is at kampi so you need to bring food (I brought a roast chicken, tomatoes lettuce and 1L water: not enough for 5 June trip. You should bring bread and light food). You need towel, change of clothes: basically a 4-5 kilo backpack. I sweated like a pig. Finally reaching the beach it was s relieve. The beach was small nice , a little different with a coconut tree and totally secluded. Australia has nicer beaches you can get to in minutes of walking. Kampi is too hard and too far to get to and is for the hardcore and misguided travelers like me. I thought of taking the boat back. It came only to deliver food to the 2 guys who were on duty. I spoke to them (they were surprised to see me and one first asked me how old I was and I said 53 and he seemed shocked: what? Haven‚Äôt seen a 53 year man do this? Apparently not. What ? so I was the first? No one this crazy I think it‚Äôs what they were thinking. Engrave my name in stone mate.) they told me that were rostered there for a week and a boat would take them back at the end of roster. They also said no one has been there for some time. When the boat came I asked the owner for a trip back and he wanted $35 ringgit which I thought was a ripoff so didn‚Äôt take it and decided to walk back. I didn‚Äôt know you had took your boat at the entrance before hand if you wanted to be picked up. (At the entrance later I found out that booking a boat was $100 per boat for max 5: regardless of person). Big mistake for now only because I Made a bad turn and went a wrong way. Told you signage was bad and I was 2 km and at least 50 mins out by the time I realised and turned back.? Total back trip was 2 hours 13 mins back with cramps and nothing left in reserved. Took a cold shower with shots and shoes on. Barely standing. Thinking of troops in jungle warfare mid way back. Very tough going not for anyone above 40 lol. This is not turtle beach. Kampi trip is in a different league. It‚Äôs a trip you really want to get lost because you are so mad and you need to channel all that madness into hiking energy. Go early back before 6 to recover. Done get lost like I did. It‚Äôs scary. No internet no communication no one there to rescue you. You run of water bad luck.no one will know or find you unless you had told someone before hand but if you got lost, then pray. Never hike alone to kampi.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: On paper this sounds like a fantastic day, an easy trek through the rainforest followed by a rest on a lovely beach and a return walk back to the little town of Teluk Bahang.The 101 bus from George Town will drop you just about at the main gates of the park where you need to register at the front office that you are taking on the walk.The path to Turtle Beach and Monkey Beach starts off well maintained and follows along a small beach before you cross a bridge and can either turn left towards Turtle Beach, or right to Monkey beach.On our trip the path to Monkey Beach was closed, they did not elaborate as to why it was closed, but closed it was.On turning left the path pretty quickly falls into major disrepair with massive erosion and wash away making it a quite difficult, slippery and dangerous climb.We can only assume that the wet season rains had caused the damage, having read a few reviews nobody else mentions them.Either way it was a more difficult and slippery climb and we were pretty happy to finally arrive at Turtle Beach to see a boatman waiting for customers.We hadn't pre-booked a boat trip back but you can just wave the guys down and negotiate a lift either back all the way or to be dropped at Monkey Beach.Turtle Beach itself was nothing much, just another ordinary beach.We're glad we did it but wouldn't do it again given the chance.On a disappointing note we saw lots of discarded plastic drinking botlles tossed down into gullies along the walk.Seriously, if you can carry the bottle in, you can carry it out.Just why you have to register will have to remain a mystery as there seems to be no follow up on leaving, you could be lost out there and nobody would ever know.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: This si the lush and verdant tropical jungle that I've always hoped to see. It was raining quite a bit on Penang, but I was determined to visit this park. I went in the afternoon hoping for a break in the weather which i got. When I registered to enter, I noticed that there were only 10 visitors that day, perfect !  When I got to the point where the trail forked, I went left into the forest instead of right where the boats to monkey beach were, as I wanted to experience the jungle without people.There you could see the canopy walk (unfortunately closed now).  I sat for awhile and took in the sights,sounds and smells of this wonderful place.It was a great retreat from the high rises of the island.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: 3 guys aged between 54 to 79 read and heard lots bout beautiful scenery n trek from Balik Pulau->Titi Kerawang Waterfalls->Teluk Bahang->Taman Negara->Pantai Kerachut->Teluk Bahang Town, total 40km.we started 0600 and throughly enjoyed the winding hill scenery with light traffic on the roads.we passed by numerous durian and nutmeg plantations and friendly stallholders where we were able to purchase reasonably priced fruits and bottled drinking water to replenish ourselves.we arrived Teluk Bahang market and had a quick Dosai meal washed down with Teh Halia aka milk ginger tea.we then walked to entrance of Taman Negara intent on visiting a meromictic lake.its a rare chance to visit a lake whereby the top layer is freshwater while lower layer is saltwater from the sea.as one of us is 79years old and unable to trek through the 2 hills with challenging slopes to Pantai Kerachut meromictic lake, we stopped and asked one of the 3 boat-trip booths for a boat ticket to fetch him to Pantai Kerachut and back.plan was us younger men, 54yo and 57yo to trek to Pantai Kerachut and meet our 79yo friend there.the booth on right offered MYR80/person on 2-way trip.we paid and left our 79yo friend in their care while we other 2 started our trek to Pantai Kerachut.btw theres a turtle hatching and conservation centre at Pantai Kerachut thus, the beach is also known as Turtle Beach.the trek was well marked with 5 well maintained shelter huts along the way.we arrived at Pantai Kerachut 3.5km after 55mins hike.beach was pristine, area clean of litter, safe with a big well marked guardhouse manned with 2 guards, well maintained jetty nearby.however, our 79yo friend did not arrive.be warned the area is devoid of any cell phone reception and attempts to call or send messages were fruitless.after waiting 1hr for our not yet arrived friend, we trekked back.however, we sent a message to our friend  hoping that once we managed to get cell phone reception it would be seen.the trek back is easier and quicker taking only 45mins back.we finally arrived back at the main entrance and received our friend‚Äôs message that he was cheated....boat only took him to nearby monkey and on pretext of trying to refuel by telling our 79yo friend that boat fuel was running low, dumped him at monkey beach and rode off leaving him stranded.fortunately, there were some other tourists who were waiting for another boat to arrive to fetch them back to Teluk Bahang,our 79yo friend pleaded with the new boatman to allow him onboard and gave him MYR10 and he was taken back.having paid MYR80 to be left stranded and another MYR10 to be taken back.our friend enquired from the other tourists how much they paid for short 2-way to Monkey Beach and was told total MYR50 for all 4 of them from another booth.we met up with him and despite this bad experience thoroughly enjoyed the trek.be aware this booth is known to have previously cheated other tourists too,the other 2 booths there after feedback from other tourists are more honest.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Previously known as the Pantai Acheh Forest Reserve, this pristine site is known to harbour 417 flora and 143 fauna species. Pantai Acheh Forest Reserve, located at the northwestern tip of Penang Island, was declared the Penang National Park in April 2003.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Easy hiking, quiet beach at turtle conservatory, food options at monkey beach. Book boat ride at headquarters if going one way.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Like everyone else, I looked up places to visit in Penang and added the national park to my list of places. But OMG. Reading about a place is one thing, visiting it is totally another experience. If you are someone who loves beaches, loves to try out new things and wants to have a mild check, you really MUST visit this place ‚ù§Ô∏è it‚Äôs unlike anything I‚Äôve ever seen before. To begin with, this is a trekking trail along the beach front. You needn‚Äôt necessarily trek, you may choose to go boating as well. There are two beaches along the shoreline - monkey beach and Kerachut beach. Unless you find it really hard to walk or are too tired, I would highly recommend that you take the trail. Ensure that you are wearing good shoes and carry water with you. After the initial five mins, you will encounter jungle trail - i.e there would no flat surface to walk upon, it is uneven walking plane with lot of stones, roots and other items along the way. But all this is an amazing experience and the beach along the walkway is secluded more often than not and you can get some really wonderful pictures ‚ù§Ô∏è we couldn‚Äôt finish our trek to the monkey beach as the trail was shut due to storm, but we did manage to go part of the way and we were mind blown! ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏èüôåüèª this is a free trail. No payment required. You will just have to register your personal details and receive a permit to enter the trail. Don‚Äôt miss this amazing experience ‚ù§Ô∏è

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Start your walk early. It is more peaceful and the temperature is kinder. Use insecticide on uncovered parts of your body. Once you get further into the park the insects suddenly pounce. Pathways are well signposted and are easy to follow. Most are very well defined.Take your time to look at the range of vegetation, you might also spot a monitor lizard waiting to catch fish on the shore. Look out for pitcher plants growing by the side of the path. There is so much to see but easily missed if you go quickly. Get a guide if you can they are very knowledgable and will make the walk more meaningful.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Penang National Park was the highlight of our trip to Malaysia. It¬¥s a small, but beautiful national park. At the time of writing the trail to the stunning Monkey Beach was close due a landslide, but this beach is still reachable by boat (80-100RM). I recommend to hike from the entrance to Turtle Beach (1 hour) and take a boat to Monkey Beach (and the entrance) from there. We paid 120RM  for this trip.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: it was a wonderful walk in the morning. the path is not very difficult from entrance to Monkey Beach. there are few routes which you can choose. such as to light house, kerachut beach & etc.this time we choose monkey beach, and we will go again for others route.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Fairly easy trail and beautiful view. My 3 children (age 6,9,11) enjoyed it very much. We walked one way and took a speedboat return.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: If you travel to Penang and get a chance go to the Monkey Beach in Penang. Great little unspoiled beach. Yes there are Monkeys but that just add the the charm and experience.It is the most warm sea water I ever experience I call only describe it as a warm bath.Because it is part of the National Park there is an entrance fee of 100 Baht per person you go on a 5-10 boat ride to reach the beach, spectacular.Very safe you tell them what time you want to get back and they come back to pick you up.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: We tried to book a tour but had no joy so decided to do it ourselves and so glad we did, it was so easy and cheap to do. Took a bus there and met another English couple so we booked a boat between us (RM80 total) to collect us from Turtle Beach. We hiked across to Turtle Beach and were glad to have taken plenty of water and some snacks as we needed them. A very hot and quite challenging hike in places.At Turtle Beache saw the meromictic lake (saltwater/freshwater) and the turtle sanctuary. Our boat dropped us at Monkey Beach which had a couple of beach cafes and bars including one up a tree. We let the cafe owner know when we wanted to head back and the boat returned to take us back to the park entrance. Due to a landslide parts of the park were closed including the canopy walkway but natural events happen. We saw monkeys, eagles, lizards and all sorts of other birds and butterflies as well as the rainforest flora.  The trip cost us around RM70 (about ¬£13) including bus fares, boat hire and a couple of beers at Monkey Beach.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Went to this park on a hot day.  Felt a little cooler because of the canopy cover. Met several people doing the same. Good walk surrounding the coast. Little bit of up and downs. Good work out while enjoying the natural beauty of the rainforest and its inhabitants I.e. monkeys and iguanas sun bathing on the rocks.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: The National Park of penang is one of the best kept secrets - few people know that the way to escape to the heat is to take a walk in the cool forests. The park is free and we arrived at 8 am. All we brought was our wallet and a bottle of water. We heard the trickle of fresh water rolling down into the sea. The trek was easy but gave us a good work out. You don‚Äôt need to be very fit but this trek is not advised for elderly or young children as there are some steep parts. The turtle Santuary was a bit of a let down - although well documented there were two large turtles putting their heads repeatedly against their tanks. Very sad, and one wonders if more can be done for them in terms of getting a larger tank - or doing away with a live display altogether.The baby turtles look fine though because their tank was so large relative to their size.We could have walked back but chanced upon a boat - and paid 80 ringgit for a quick but bumpy ride back. Set aside half a morning for this.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: * Entrance fee free of charge* Trekking course map(attached by a photo)* Its natural and wild character made me experience the shortest course, Turtle Beach. It takes total 2~3 hours(dependant on one's condition) with 4Km-long distance. It leads to the untouched beautiful beach through wild woods with a lot of sounds of unknown animals. I think this trekking may be one of activities in hottest afternoon in Penang.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: We trekked to the beach and it took us an hour or two, which was nice as we could really take in the rain forest surroundings. The beach at the end was also nice to sit on, although we couldn't go into the sea as it was wavy. Unfortunately we went in a national holiday and the turtle sanctuary was closed. We arranged a boat to take us back but it was 2 hours late and may not have came if the guard on the beach hadn't have phoned the company, so watch our for that.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: 15 minutes drive from Batu Ferringhi, parking costs 3 rgts. No entry fee for the park. Take your passport as you do have to register and may have to show it. Once you pass through the stone arch and into the park you're in a different world. It took me just over an hour to reach 'Turtle beach', where the sanctuary is. I spent an hour there so a round trip of a bit over 3 hours. I set of at 10 am and saw no-one until I got to the beach. There were about half a dozen people on the return walk, so not at all busy. A lovely beach. Saw Macaques, Dusky Leaf Monkeys (Spectacled Langurs) and Monitor lizards.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: We had booked a guide which was invaluable as he took us for a 3hour trek in the forest.  He was excellent and identified many plants and insects.  We saw 2 species of monkey and a number of very large monitor lizards.Well worth a trip.  Be warned the humidity is bad!!

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Last weekend I visited the National Park of Penang. I had looked forward, but it was a sad experience. At the gate office, we met an official, who was more interested in his mobile phone, than visitors. "It is free, so sign in" No other information. The trail to Monkey Beach was closed and the Canopy walk was close. No money and no maintenance of the park. We went to the Kerchut beach on the other side of the park. One and a half hours walk and most of the trail was fine. Facilities on the beach also closed. One can only hope that the Government of Penang will again upgrade this park.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: The 2 things we really wanted to do were the canopy walk, which has been closed now for 6 yrs so why are they still advertising it and monkey beach which we couldn't trek to die to a landslide. You can go part way o. Foot then get a boat there. The lady selling the boats trips by the main entrance is more expensive than the park themselves when you register.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: We spent a very enjoyable few hours exploring the park during a hike across to Kerachut (turtle) beach.  The park entry is free, just fill in visitor details at the kiosk.We were pestered quite a bit by local boat tour companies for trips to the beaches, but we just politely declined.The walk starts on a well maintained, paved path alongside the shoreline.  We saw a few water monitors basking in the sun.  After a small fotbridge the path forks left to Kerachut, right to monkey beach.From here there is a fairly steep climb up into the trees.  There is a rope to assist at the side and in some places concrete steps.  The climb soon becomes less steep and from here on it's a pleasant hike, which suddenly emerges out onto a stunning beach after about 1hr 15mins walking.At one time efforts have been made to install concrete steps on most of the route, but in the main nature has won, with tree roots and earth breaking them up.  So you do have to watch your step.We were there after a long period of dry weather so the ground was completely dry, but i could see that after rain sections of the path would become very muddy, so would advise sturdy footwear.Unfortunately, due to the long dry spell the meromictic was dry, but could see where the waterline would be and am sure it's an impressive sight when full.There are interesting information bords doted along the route, which gave the perfect opportunity to stop for a breather.  There are also several pagodas with shaded benches for a break.The whole route was litter free and there was none on the beach either.While we stopped for our packed lunch on the beach numerous boats came by, seeking passengers for the trip back to the park entrance, so that could be an option if you didn't fancy the walk. Overall we had a great few hours out exploring in the nature and would recommend it to anyone who fancies a bit of a jungle adventure without too much of a physical challenge!

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Epic hike in some spectacular jungle. Catch the 101 bus from Penang to the end of the line. Hike to the beach took me 1 hour thus a return trip is 2-3 hours including lunch stop. Monkey Beach was inaccessible at the time due to a recent mudslide blocking the path. However charter tourists boats were offering the opportunity to visit the beach at a price for those desperate to see monkeys! I would highly recommend bringing 2-3 litres of water plus some good footwear. Trainers are OK but they will get muddy. The traverse also covers two prominent hills so a good general level of fitness is required. Children over the age of 6 should be OK.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Penang National Park is a beautiful place to visit. Upon arrival there are stands where local boat companies are selling tickets to take you to different islands. You do not NEED to take a boat to get to the islands and you can hike to them through the park instead. We had planned to hike to Turtle Beach and had intention on camping there. The lady at the boat told us that in order to camp at Turtle Beach we needed a guide, so she suggested we hike there and then take a boat to Monkey Beach for camping, to avoid having a guide. The hike to Turtle Beach was about 1 hour, maybe a little less, and wasn‚Äôt very difficult. When we arrived there, it was pretty empty and for a couple hours we were the only foreigners on the island. At Turtle Beach you are not permitted to swim in the water and the sanctuary was closed in February, so we didn‚Äôt get to see turtles. The beach was absolutely beautiful and and we even saw a sea lion swimming and rolling around on the beach near us. After a few hours the boat we arranged to pick us up showed up at the dock and took us to Monkey Island. The boat ride was 100RM which gave us a boat to ourselves, but that was because we paid at the entrance of the park. I would suggest waiting at the island and then paying the driver when you want to leave because others that got on the boat only paid 10RM, since they were sharing our boat (the money went to the driver). Planning ahead is not necessary to take a boat to Monkey Beach from Turtle Beach, and you can hike in between them easily if you don‚Äôt want to take a boat. Monkey Beach was not as beautiful and secluded as Turtle Beach. There were quite a few locals renting tents, selling drinks, and food during the daytime. The beach was not as clean but still nice to relax. You can pay to rent a tent there or you can pitch your own tent free of charge. We had our camping equipment so we decided to do the latter. Sleeping on the beach was an event in itself. The waves were loud and big during the night and there were plenty of little creatures moving around near us. There were also LOTS of mosquitoes. Overall it was a good camping experience, just be prepared for heat, mosquitoes, and creatures roaming near your tent at night. The following day we relaxed on some lounge chairs and swam in the water to cool down from the heat. The boat driver picked us up from Monkey Beach and took us back to the pier. Again, I recommend just paying a driver at the beach instead of planning ahead, unless you have a group larger than five, because there are loads of boats coming and going all day to take you back. The picture is of Turtle Beach, I do not have one of Monkey Beach.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: I agree with what others reviewers said about the maintainence of Monkey Beach, indeed found some trash including plastic bags and empty water bottles along the beach, but it's still pleasant with several Monkeys (they do steal your bag/food, so watch out) and a good hike to the Light house (where has a good view of fresh water meeting the salt water but nothing awesome).My pov regarding boat taxi, I don't know about other boat taxis but the one I had (I forgot the name but you'll find them after and inside the 1st entry gate, square where you register) was great! Very informative, good price (Monkey Beach round trip was 80MYR per BOAT, we were 3, so I paid 27MYR) and overall the nicest people that helped me even thou I didn't ask (borrow me slippers, exchanged money, stopped at bus station just to say that there's a local market open so bus will not stop at the station many of us were waiting). Since I believe nice people should be rewarded, I'm writing this review down for them. BEST

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Been there in year 2012, have beautiful view when reached the light house. Revisited this national park again, but those bridge broken. Take 2 hours  reached, with good stamina maybe can completed in 1 hour 30 min.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: Please local authorities, clean your beaches, monkeys playing with plastic bottles and not stuff that has been washed ashore. Officials checking passports wasting time, (pointless exercise) get litter sweepers on the beach, encourage the boat taxis to get involved etc! grrrrrrrrr!!

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: There is no entry fee but you need to register. Frankly, I would rather they charged something and use the money to clean up the place. That being said, I would recommend visiting just for the nice walk and the beach. The paved walkway up to the forest is along an extremely dirty stretch of beach. Keep walking straight and ignore it, be careful of monkeys as they tried to snatch my friend's water bottle (plain yellow with no dangly bits). If you can get past the rickety bridge, the hike starts becoming a lot more pleasant. We did the Pantai Kerachut hike, which was around 3.5km one way. There are a lot of steep parts with broken steps, but very doable. People with knee or ankle issues should bring a walking stick and take their time. Go early in the morning, before 9am. It can get warm. Bring a lot of water. You can spot a lot of wildlife if you pay attention. You don't need to hike the meromictic lake trail to see the lake, as it's right next to Kerachut Beach. We went during the dry season, so the lake was mostly dry. The beach itself is nice. Bring a beach towel to sit on and have a picnic or a nap under the trees. It's clean and there weren't a lot of people there even though the other trail (Monkey Beach) was closed due to a landslide.

Name: Penang National Park (Taman Negara Pulau Pinang)
Comment: The National Park is failing in its duties here.The place is filthy. The beach covered in crap, and the boat mafia charging whatever they like to gullible tourists.Clean this place up. Enforce litter fines, make the food places, and watersports/boat people compliant with conservation rules. Stop them scamming people with their pricing!Really sad.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Worth a visit to this family farm especially for children. It is small but the farm has goats, chickens, goose, peacock, deer and little furries like guinea pig, rabbits and sugar glider and chicks. They have one breed of chicken, Cochin which is huge. You need to rent a car to drive up as it can be hard to find your way back if you do not. Grab cars may only fetch you there but not back.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: My kids have experience to feed to goat and feel the hand touching. Witnesses for milk taken process, they are knowing how the milk been process. Have fresh goat milk in store and my kids like the Goat Milk Ice-Cream and Goat Milk yogurt.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: This is a small family farm. Good visit for families with young children.  The goats are penned and you can wander through the pen and pet the animals. There are rabbits galore, guinea pigs, an ostrich, tortoise, deer, chickens, dogs and a sugar glider...

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: My entire family loved this place. This place has some of the friendliest animals I've seen in any place. While I was parking my car, several curious cats and dogs came out to greet me and these animals will nuzzle against you and invite you to pet them. The goats are also very friendly. There are also chickens and we also saw a goose and ostrich. You can feed the goats without paying but watch out for your head as the goat shed is a bit low. Compared to similar farms, the animals looked reasonably clean and well-cared for. We also tried the ice cream and yoghurt which were good.We will come again if we are in the area.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: The animals are well kept. There are goat, rabbit, chicken, duck, dog, and emu in the farm. It is a small farm and the operators sells animals feed. There are also free grass as animal feeds. Free Entrance for all. I did not try the goat milk and pudding but these item look fresh.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: I have been here for several times with my friends, buddies, gf and also family members.It is a place where you can find some cool animals and you feed the animals there. You have no worries if you feel thirsty or might feel hungry over there as they sell some dairy products which you can stuff it.The entrance is free and your kids will love this place!

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: We saw this on one of those listicles on family-friendly spots in Penang and decided to make a trip out of it.It's a little out of way but definitely worth it if you have children.Entry to the farm is absolutely free, and you can see that a lot of care has been put into the place. The goat pens are simple and rustic, but designed with ventilation in mind, and it was very enjoyable watching the children get up close to the animals.Make sure you grab the Napier grass that is provided at the entrance, so you can feed the goats. Some of them are allowed to roam freely so look out for hungry mouths that are more than happy to chew on your shirt, pants and shoes! Haha.There are also other animals to look at - an ostrich, a peacock, geese, a deer, prairie dogs, mini chickens, sugar gliders etc etc - but the goats are definitely the highlight.This is a family-run enterprise, and since they don't charge admission fees, it seems a no-brainer to support the space by purchasing cute keychains, nutritious goat's milk, and absolutely yummy goat's milk ice cream!HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. Especially if you have little ones.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Just 30 min drive from Teluk Bahang , if you are going to Balik Pulau, this is a must see if you are travelling with kids .Get to play with the animals.Very well maintained and good

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Didn‚Äôt know we were coming here but it was an enjoyable side trip. My son was not having a great day until we came here. He loves animals and the cats, dogs, goats, ostrich were what he needed to cheer up. There are other animals there such as peacocks, geese, a deer among them but for him the cats and kids were the best. One kid in particular followed him around and ‚Äòchewed‚Äô on our clothing. Very adorable. And the cats and kittens were so friendly. One slept on a weighing scale and one was wedged and sleeping in a small pail. The goat ice cream was delicious on a hot & humid day. Not a large place but fun nevertheless.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: We visited this farm as part of a guided bike ride. Although the caged goats seemed a bit cruel, it‚Äôs always hard to judge other cultures. The hosts were really friendly and the goats milk ice cream hit the spot on a hot day. Also they had loads of small kittens, so my kids loved it.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: We didn't know where we were going in our bike tour, but our guide took us to his family's farm. At first glance, it looked ordinary, but as we spent more and more time here we saw so many amazing things. There was a huge variety of animals, dogs, cats, rabbits, deer, an ostrich, peacocks, roosters, chickens, and 150 goats! We were given some grass to feed the goats and they are so cute and friendly! Our guide also showed us to the ostrich, who was very funny. Our guide would hold out his hand and the ostrich would just peck it! We were also given free samples of the ice cream which was fantastic and we also had some goats milk yoghurt, which was great. We were also shown to the things they grow, and he showed us nutmeg, pineapples and more. It was very interesting, and credit to our guide, he was very intelligent and funny.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Plenty of apparently content goats, kept protected from the oppressive heat from a farm on stilts letting plenty of air circulation, very friendly daughter of the owner, with perfect command of English, and an excellent goat ice cream. Superb!

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: At first I was not having great impression  but I was too soon to 'Judge a book by it's cover".  Arrived at the farm with great good impression.  The farm was tidy and neat. It can be more improvement.   Is a great addition for Balik Pulau and make the island interesting for locals and interesting place to visit

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Came here as part of a tour of things in the area (with a driver). There were a TON of goats in two very small pens, and they looked dirty and not particularly well cared for, and had barely any room to roam. Therefore, we did not stay long or sample the products. Sad to have these beautiful creatures in what seemed like poor conditions. There was also an ostrich in a very small pen on site. Not what I was expecting as someone who loves goats and was very excited to come here

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: You are allowed to pet and feed the goats, as well as most other animals there. Do buy the products there as they are not too pricey and quite delicious...

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Okay gotta admit the drive there was super challenging & long. but it was worth it! The owner was very friendly and taught us many things about their beloved animals. The sheeps are soooo cute :') so lovely! the dogs also! they have rabbits, chickens, and ostrich!buy their goat milk when you're about to leave cause theirs were so fresh & homemade. Unfortunately we don't have ice-cooler otherwise we would've buy more. plus, it was cheap! Hope one day their goat milk will be marketed outside the farm.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: It is a small family-run goat farm. The entrance is free but visitors can help to support the farm by buying their fresh goat milk, yogurt & other products. The location is quite difficult to find as it is located within a village. But, it is worth a visit to get away from the hustle & bustle of the city. There are also other animals within the compound; geese, chickens, ducks, deer and even an ostrich. Once you arrived, you will be greeted by the host's friendly dogs and cats too.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: I never knew goats had the weirdest rectangular irises!  Freaked me out big time!  The farm is just that.  Two buildings with lots of goats.  Lots.  You can smell your way there.The goats are all penned.  No free wandering for them just the humans.  Some looked very uncomfortable because I think they should have been milked much earlier.  I found that a bit sad. There are no guides/explanations about the process.  There is a teenaged girl at the coffee shop like building in front and there's goat's milk for sale should you want to try.  There are also various goat milk products.Rectangular irises!  I learned that.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: If you are looking for something a bit out of the norm, this is the place to go. The goats are cute and gentle, the produce is delicious. Very informative and friendly owner! During our visit, we get to see a mother giving birth. It was a new experience to us. A great one!

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: We visited Saanen Dairy Goat Farm, as part of a self-organised tour to Entopia and Bao Sheng Durian Farm as well. Do note that if you take a grab to the farm, it might be worthwhile to get the driver to wait as it is quite hard to get a grab out of the farm! (The owners are very sweet and will find ways to help you though).The farm is rather small and it‚Äôs free admission. You can pick up stalks of grass to feed the goats though and you can also step into the goats‚Äô pen. There are other animals like chickens, rabbits, an ostrich, a deer and some dogs too. They also sell an assortment of dairy goat products like goats milk, yogurt, and even popsicles. Do support the farm by purchasing some goods!

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: It's a family running goat farm & producing some related products to sell. Fresh goat milk & ice cream are refreshing & priced reasonable. There are a few rabbits, dogs, chicken, ostrich as well. The farm is hidden in a village & might difficult to call for uber. A good place to‚Ä¶

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: The ice cream rivals Italian gelato - yoghurt drinks are delicious too - they had sold out of full cream yoghurt so I will have to go back - lovely people run it. The animals are all very well cared for.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: A great great place for animal lovers.  Upon arrival, we were warmly welcomed by the owner‚Äôs wife and daughters, and their pets (12 dogs and 8 cats, I believe).  Spent a great deal of time with the pets, and chatting with the ladies.  They gave very good advice of attractions‚Ä¶

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: This is my first time visiting a goat farm. It was a wonderful experience to meet the goats and other animals. They are very well cared for. The farm is well equipped for visitors with WiFi and a stall selling goat products. Just be aware that it is far away from George Town and‚Ä¶

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: The location of Saanen farm is at the other side of Penang which took us 45min by Grab from Georgetown. Even thou the journey looked long, we found it bearable.  Before we decided to visit the farm, I did contact the owner of the farm to find out about their soap lesson. After a‚Ä¶

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: There are three farms in Balik Pulau. But this is the most famous one! The entrance is free! You didn't hear me wrong! It is totally FREE!!! You can see, touch and feed the goat. There are free leaves for you to feed the goat. You can see how they milk the goat too.You have the chance to see guinea pigs, ostrich, deer, chickens, goose and dogs. The ice cream is a must-try dessert!!!

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: This a great place to visit. The farm is not near to town (kind of out of nowhere) but it is a 'must' visit place. Visit is not only free but visitors are given grass to feed the goats. The farm is clean and stench free! Some of the tame goats and kids are allowed to roam freely. The owner also reared ostrich, cats, dogs and rabbits in the farm.Besides goats,

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: The goat milk was the best I had ever tasted - fresh and doesn't carry a strong flavor that made many people avoid it. The yogurt and ice-cream were delectable! We tried the original yogurt, mango yogurt and green tea ice cream flavours and loved all of them! The family who owns this farm are people who truly loves animals. They know every one of their animals at their finger tips. It's definitely an animals' paradise and the animals were healthy and happy. Many animals like dogs, cats, chickens, even goats roam around the farm freely.If you wish to enjoy the farm environment with your children, need to ensure they handle the animals with tender love and care. Shouting, taunting and running about tends to scare and disturbs the animals. My teenager loves this farm. We returned to the farm on second day at her request. Each visit, we spent at least 2 hours there interacting comfortably with the animals, owners and other visitors. They don't charge any entrance free for visiting. So to contribute to the operation of this lovely farm, we drank/ate/bought all the goats' milk, yogurt and ice cream that we possibly could for our entire Penang trip! ;)

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: I enjoyed every single trip I've taken here. The owners were friendly and extremely down to earth. You get to feed the goats for free and roam around their farm. They have some vegetables planted at the back. Just lookout for the angry geese! ;)

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Ads a commercial venture to extract goat mil and make ice-cream is to be coended in spite of heat issue which were well accommodated with fans and air-con for the goats.Demonstrations of dragon fruit peling and bees etc were good. However it was let down by the keeping of an Ostrich in a small caged are permanently. There was a 2nd one a few weeks ago which accidentally hung itself apparently. So sad to see a big bird like this unable to be able to run around.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: FREE!!!  It was awesome.  The yogurt drink is to try.  We had passion fruit and nutmeg.  Nutmeg was good.  We also tried the ice-cream.  And it was very creamy and smooth.  Very nice indeed.  We were given an elephant grass each to feed the goats.  And those little kids were roaming free in the farm.  There was also a session of milking the goats.  Overall, it was nice.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: This is our first visit to Saanen goat farm located at Balik Pulau. Be sure to come here with a driver or arrange for pick up after your visit else you will be stuck with no way to go back as the farm is far from the main town. Luckily we hired a driver who waited for us during the whole trip. I love this farm, so does my 2 young children. We can get close up to the goats and  baby goats and even pat and carry the baby goats. The goats are so loving to humans and its very safe to be near them.The farm also sells goat milk which is the tastiest I've drank so far with no smell. The girl who takes care of the milk stall is friendly and she even kept all her small dogs as my family is afraid of dogs. Farm is clean and there is a toilet for visitors. Free admission and no time limit. 2 hours would be more than enough at this farm.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: A family-friendly goat farm and we have brought friends and relatives there three times for goat feeding and milk products. It can be a bit difficult to find for first timers. Saanen is Swiss breed, highly productive dairy goat. Male goats are bigger in size and are usually weighted at 100kg and above. Female goats are smaller and are usually weighted at 80kg and below. Grass is available in the premise FOC and each visitor is allowed to bring a bunch of it to feed the furkids in the barn. Goat milk products such as fresh goat milk, nutmeg yogurt drink, goat milk pudding, and goat milk brown sugar bun are available for sales. Free admission.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Again no entrance fee, my driver just take some vegetable for us to feed the goats. Maybe we come a wrong timing, all goats are sleeping. The little goats are not in cage, you can touch them easily. The visit is very short, only about 30 mins. There are also 2 ostriches, 2 lambs and some chicken and ducks in the farm. There is a shop selling goat milk and goat yogurt.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: The place is a liitle of the track (8km off Pulau Balik town) and need a vehicle to get to.Entry is free but RM7 to join the mini tour. In return you get to know about the goats (some interesting facts), feed/pet/carry(if there are recently born babies) the goats, see the milking process (machine though), a complimentary bottle of goat milk/padding/ice cream. Well worth the RM7 price!The owner (& daugther) are very friendly and will answer all your questions.The farm also have some other interesting animals - prairie dog, hedgehog, "trophy chicken", a special kind of the bee (the nest, in hollow tree trunk, is not the usual honeycomb shape but rather like alien space pods! Really got to see them!).Overall a great place to spend a whole morning (including travelling time to/fro if staying near Georgetown).

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: When we went there, it was full of kids and people, there were not only goat but also some goose, chicken, ostrich etc.  The farmer here also makes compose, so if you are a gardener, you can talk to the farmer.  They will also give you a free tour if they are free. You also get‚Ä¶

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: The goats are friendly and touchable. Feeding grass is free as well as entrance. Goat milk pudding was nice. Quite clean and well maintained. Definitely a thumbs up.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: It's not easy to get here but if you are interested .... sure it's good enough. You will see plenty of goats, and their is goat milk and yogurt sold. You need your own transport, so get a taxi as the bus requires you to walk for a good 20 minutes to the farm (get off at Sungai‚Ä¶

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: You can feed & touch goats freely. You got to know many info about goats, milk, yogurts, etc ... Goat milk is the best, very fresh & taste great! My 2 girls enjoyed a lot feeding, touching goats, playing with the dogs & cats, etc ...

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: You get the experience to feed the goats, touch and even hug. Try to avoid holiday season as the goats will be lazy to eat your feeding due to overwhelming of visitors feeding them whole day. Aside of goats, you have chance to see ostrich as well. Must try the goat milk, tasty‚Ä¶

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Not easy access unless you drive, but great place for kids. Owners are very friendly. This was our 2nd visit and we were lucky this time to view the goats being milked. Always very exciting for kids to be able to feed the goats. Good learning experience as well.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: This place is easy to locate by GPS. The farm is not big but is a nice place to encounter with goats. Plenty of grass given by the owner so you can feed goats. The goats is clean no worry. They are also selling some goats' products such as goat milk & bun. Must try!

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: We arrived in a mess of tourists harassing a few puppies with no one from the property around to supervise and perhaps protect the poor animals from all the children mishandling them and enthusiast parents taking photos.....Said puppies had no water, no shade on a very hot afternoon and were kept in a tiny cage. Had a quick look at the goats which are staying in quite dirty conditions and have to put up with hordes of children running around and harassing them. A big no, and I would discourage anyone from visiting such a horrible place.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Plan it as part of your holiday excursion if you're stopping by Balik Pulau for half day to enjoy lustrous tropical fruit and kampung (village) life after intoxicating yourself with busy Penang city/beach visit, and if you want your kids to learn something educational. It is located near Ghee Hup Nutmeg Factory (5min drive) and Audi Dream Farm (5min drive). Best time to come when you've durian, rambutan and mangosteen season in sight (May-July) as you can see how these plants bear fruits along with the nutmeg trees.The goat milk is tasty, the owner even demonstrates on how goat milking is done. You have to queue up to perform the hands-on experience though. We did not make it as queue is long (1 whole load of school bus kids are queuing ahead of us), and my disinterested almost teenage city boys. You can see how goats interacts within themselves with headbutting and bleating. It was fun. Very limited smell due to good ventilation (at the time we're there), and the place are pretty clean too with workers feeding and cleaningWith kids, I think it is easy to spend 0.5 to 1hr there depending on activities that you want to participate on. Greatest thing of all this is all free with no obligation to pay any fee, on top of friendly owner who speaks fluent Mandarin (or Hokkien, can't recall) on top of some of English.Sign up to learn on how to milk a goat, it is an experience of life for city dwellers like us.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: It is a long drive from Batu ferringhi with sharp and curvy roads. The place is small and  simple and the best thing is that it is free. The owners are friendly and accommodating.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: It's free of charge. Worth to pay a visit. My kid is having a great time feeding the goats. The grass is also free of charge! Great experience as we can be so near to the goats. The place can be found via waze  but it is a bit far from Penang town. Most importantly the place is not crowded with tourist. After feeding the goats we can try the goats milk/ yogurt/ mantou. The place is also clean and not too hot.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: A. How could anyone not love a goat.B. They are dairy goats so there is nothing traumatic to explain to the kids. C. The goat milk pudding is delicious. D. The goats are clean, healthy, well fed and well cared for. The pens are clean and clearly cleared out and scrubbed daily.We've been twice now, once on our own and once with the kids. The goats are clearly used to socializing and love nothing better than a bit of a cuddle, lick and head butt. Fun for everyone and tucked away in a lovely part of Penang that gives you a feeling for what life might have been like in other parts of Penang in the past.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: You can get close to goat, which most of us do not have the chance to do it. You can feed them with special grass that prepared by owner. See how they eat and observe their action. You also can taste the fresh goat milk (really tasty, must try).Need to improve so more activity can be carried out.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: No entrance fee is charged and you are given free grasses to experience feeding the goat. The goats are all clean and not smelly. Get to see young, adult and pregnant goats. Goats milk, ice cream, snack and soap are all sold there. Not big compound but appreciate this access to my favorite animal!

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Finally visited after reading about it some time ago. A really fun and great trip, different from all the usual "tourist attractions" experience. Not a lot of people know about this place so it's not very crowded at all. There are baby dairy goats to adult ones and it's totally okay to touch/pet them! It's a rather small farm but there are other animals like puppies and bunnies to see as well. Friendly owner, entrance and grass feeding is free and there are some dairy products for sale. Recommended for anyone of any age to visit!

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: The goats are healthy, clean n no weird smell. Well manage n worth a visit if u happen to go Balik Pulau..Might need a chinese speaking translation for the tour n the owner can converse abit in english..not bad!

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Clean place, friendly owner explanation. Organic & tasty foods made by goat mill (i.e bun, ice cream, milk, yoghurt) and also simple souvenir for u to take home (fridge magnet, key chain)

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Located Far from the city! Free grass to feed the goats!!! Really worth the good with our tour!! Refer to pictures!! Best of the best!

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: The goats are adorable! The farm was a little far but we were exploring Balik Pulau and Pulau Betong so we dropped by. Used 'waze' to get there. The owner was friendly, and he was happy we visited. The place was clean, well kept. We bought some goats milk ice cream and it was delicious! He ran out of goats milk soap tough. Everything was made there. I bought a bottle of goats milk to take home. Admission free. Free feeding grass for the goats who will let you pet them.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm is a small place actually but its a clean and well maintain place, you can have grass tor free to feed the goat and pat them .. admission is free .. it is a nice place to visit.http://pinkypigletland.blogspot.com/2015/07/saanen-goat-farm-penang.html

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: It is a good experience and very friendly environment .superb goat ice cream .highly recommended to visit as it is very near the tropical fruit farm.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: The farm is very neat and clean. Also,the goats are very adorable and we love feeding them with the grasses which are FOC. There are some foods and souvenirs available for purchase too such as goat's ice-cream, fresh goat's milk and even goat's soap!! This was an amazing experience indeed.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: We have heard of this place for awhile so the 1st weekend of the school holidays in June we went along with our grandchildren and their parents.Entrance to the goat farm is free, and they also offer free grass which one can take to feed the goats. We did enjoy that very much.The goats were very clean and well-kept.We could see the goats being milked using modern equipments.They had some goat's milk items for sale, such as pudding, bread, and ice-cream.Besides the goats, there was also a lot of vegetation at the farm. We took some pictures of the winter melon plant and there was even a grape vine and mulberry bush and of course the local fruits such as dragon fruits,Durians and mangosteens.You can check out their Facebook page  for more photos and information.We went early as it was hot and as the day went by the crowed started coming so we left just before noon and all of us had a good morning outing.Apparently these snow white goats are natives from Switzerland.One caution please use mosquito repellent before going.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Nice place to visit for children. With free entrance, parents can bring their kids to learn about goats. There is also an organic farm near the goat farm.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: This is a family owned goat farm. There is no admission fee needed for visitor and  you can get a stalk of free grass to feed the goats. And there is also goat milking explanation from the owner and you can see that process closely. The farm is clean and organized, and it is one of the must visit attraction if you are touring around Balik Pulau.There are some goat dairy product sold e.g. ice cream, hot bun, yogurt, fresh milk and some souvenirs.I highly recommend this place for family and kids may love this farm very much.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: It's a country side mainly shows an agriculture environment with few farmers.They rare goats in this place near Pantai Aceh.very interesting by touching them and blend the farmers experience together. Really fantastic fresh goat milk you can enjoy there and it's more fun,if it is in the fruits seasonal time in Penang on Jun,July,August.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: I really love Saanen Dairy Goat Farm. I can feel the owner's love for the goats by the amazingly well-mantained farm. Adorable goats, especially the little ones... I can't get enough of their cuteness... A must visit while in Penang.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: This is a very well maintained goat farm not far from the tropical fruit farm.  The owner family takes very good care of the goats.  We had a tour of the milking process, and had some wonderfully fresh goat milk.  This farm does not charge any admission fees, and makes its profits purely from selling their products such as goat milk.  All the products are very fresh and very reasonably priced.  It is a real bargain, and is a great experience for any children or adults who enjoy nature and the outdoor.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Very detailed explanation by the young manager, showing enthusiasm on this field. Fresh dairy products are available. Be reminded to come before noon to witness the process of milking the goats.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: This is one of my children's favorite place in Penang that they must visit every year. Living in the city, our children hardly see live animals and they love the touch with the animals. The farm is out of the busy city in Penang located in Balik Pulau. The enjoyed feeding the goats and hugging the kids (baby goats) which are outside the pens, taking pictures with them. The owner and his family are very friendly, if they are not too busy they are able to chat with you and recommend you the nice places to visit in Balik Pulau. If you are travel in a group, you can call them in advance and they will arrange briefing for you about the goats and the farm.Another attraction for my children is they love the fresh goats' milk and also the yogurt drinks from the farm. You can buy some frozen milk or yogurt to bring home.

Name: Saanen Dairy Goat Farm
Comment: Just have to walk in to the farm, you can have test drink for the fresh goat milk. Is very fresh!Somemore you can experience very close distance with the cute goat. Is a very nice place if you wanna spend a eco tour in Penang.

Name: The Floating Mosque
Comment: I'd say this is an interesting place to swing by on the way up to the north of the island but it's not going to blow your mind.Go at high tide to get better photos, try to avoid their prayer times if possible so you can walk around inside. They give you the clothing required all free of charge.

Name: The Floating Mosque
Comment: On our way to visit Gurney drive night market at Batu Feringghi, we visit this place as planned and this half an hour break worth it.There are numerous landmarks in Penang that are sights to behold. One of them is none other than the Floating Mosque of Tanjung Bungah. Situated along Tanjung Bungah‚Äôs stretch of beach, gives a 360-degree panoramic view of the sea.It‚Äôs the first mosque in the country to be built on the sea, with pillars and stilts supporting its majestic structure.Tanjung Bungah is pretty quiet when compared to its more touristy neighbors, Batu Feringghi, Gurney and Georgetown.Watching the boats on the sea near beach in evening make you will feel like its a picture from any fantasy novel. You will definitely love the scenic beauty of the place and peacefulness.You can‚Äôt miss Tanjung Bungah as the place is on the way to Batu Feringghi ‚Äì just make sure you don‚Äôt forget to stop by and pay a visit.

Name: The Floating Mosque
Comment: This is definitely worth a visit. The friendly guy at the door will look after your dress code needs and answer any questions. The outside is a little more interesting than inside, but for those who haven't visited a mosque before, this would be a comfortable start.

Name: The Floating Mosque
Comment: It is a nice place, with guided tours also, and a very comfy place for Muslims to offer their prayers. I visited this place with my wife and daughter. it's very windy and by the beautiful beach gives you a panoramic view of Penang. My family loves it.

Name: The Floating Mosque
Comment: It‚Äôs not that special. Quirky as it‚Äôs in the sea, on stilts, not really floating. Worth going to have a look if you‚Äôre passing, but that‚Äôs it.

Name: The Floating Mosque
Comment: This must be a beautiful mosque for prayer, but for a tourist it is not really worth the trip at all.

Name: The Floating Mosque
Comment: We have stopped during our day tour to perform prayers. Mosque was breath capturing with amazing view,indoor  articature

Name: The Floating Mosque
Comment: I'm surprised that there are people writing bad reviews for the fact that the mosque does not truly float on water, since common sense suggests that it is built on stilts and simply looks as if it is floating on water depending on the tide. Visitors should manage their expectations accordingly. However, I personally found the mosque beautiful with sea views. As with many places of worship, we were asked to cover our exposed body and hair if we wanted to enter the Prayers Hall, and clothes and scarves were provided free of charge. Otherwise, if we were not agreeable to the dress code, we were allowed to walk outside the Prayers Hall and take photographs. We were given a free guided tour for around half an hour, during which we learnt more about the architecture and history of the mosque as well as beliefs and practices of Islam. It was an insightful tour and we were never made to feel uncomfortable even though we had different ethnic and religious backgrounds. There was also a rack of informative brochures. I particularly recommend the brochures "About Islam: A Brief Introduction" and "Misconceptions About Islam". Overall, this was a beautiful mosque and I learned a lot. I highly recommend visitors in the Batu Ferringhi area to visit this mosque.

Name: The Floating Mosque
